story:
The Men of Raven 23

All decorated combat veterans working for the Department if State, these four men’s lives converged in Iraq nearly 12 years ago. Read more about each man by clicking on his link:

  • Nicholas Slatten http://www.supportraven23.com/nick-slatten
  • Evan Liberty http://www.supportraven23.com/evan-liberty
  • Dustin Heard http://www.supportraven23.com/dustin-heard
  • Paul Slough http://www.supportraven23.com/paul-slough

Never before and never since have any of these men been accused of misconduct in any professional or military capacity and all are decorated combat veterans. Due to case dismissals for constitutional rights violations, it took seven years for the initial case to go to trial. Since 2014, one man, Nick Slatten, has gone through two more trials (again due to constitutional rights violations against him)l while the other three languish in prison with no sentences, due to the fact their original sentences were deemed unconstitutional.

Get full details and read up on past issues of the newsletter by going to our website at www.freeraven23.com 

What We Need

  • First and foremost we need exposure, please take to your social media, or tweet the President and your representatives and hashtag #freeraven23
  • Contact your state representatives via email or phone and ask them to review the case for pardon support. It’s ok not to know everything if you ask them to just look into it - we understand 12 years of case history can be hard to digest.
  • If you feel led, you can share funds with us through this campaign. Mounting legal fees and single income families (some with children) are strenuous.

The Impact

Your choice to share your hard earned money with us can make a huge difference,

  • Our legal funds have run dry and the Slough family has put up tens of thousands of dollars for attorneys to seek a pardon for the men of Raven 23. You can help!
  • Every family has mounting bills, no income from their incarcerated veteran and have been taking care of financial matters on their own for four long years.
  • All four men receive commissary funds each month, up to $500 each so that they can purchase food, hobby supplies, mailing materials, email and call home.

In Summary 

Most of all, we ask people to look at both sides of the story - not just the one that the government told that was presented in the media. As a matter of fact, we were instructed by the judge not to interact in the media... so we have never been given the opportunity to defend ourselves our publicly. By the time they were convicted the damage had been done and people’s minds were made up... However, by the grace of God alone, we had been offered new opportunities to give the public and our administration the complete picture and ask for your help in doing so.

story:
Please help me raise the amount for Proud Lebanon so can be organized 2 LGBTIQ+ themed events.

What is Proud Lebanon?
Proud Lebanon is a non-profit, non-religious, non-political, non-partisan civil society that aims to promote sustainable social & economic development in Lebanon and the region and is working to achieve protection, empowerment and equality of marginalized groups through community service activities.

Proud Lebanon started its activities in August 2013 and is registered since April 2014 as a non-profit civil society.
Among the communities Proud Lebanon is working to assist, there is the LGBTIQ+ community, the people living with HIV, the Refugees in Lebanon and the Prisoners.

Proud Lebanon's Mission

Proud Lebanon aims to empower people who suffer from discrimination.
We are dedicated to promote tolerance in Lebanon and the region, where people are effectively empowered and to ensure the well-being of individuals.

Proud Lebanon's Vision

To reach a world where there is no violence, discrimination or violations of human rights, where all people live equally in dignity, freedom and inner peace.

Budget as many NGOs, Proud Lebanon have faced some financial obstacles and to be able to continue answering the needs of the community, Proud Lebanon is asking for your support to be able to continue its mission and to maintain its services running effectively.  

How you can help?

Any contribution can make a change, make sure that every penny can contribute and help us reach our goal.
But If you can't directly contribute by donating online, you can still help us by sharing this campaign and spreading the word to your friends and contacts.
You may reach us at anytime on our E-mail: info@ProudLebanon.org or by calling us on: +961.76.608205

General overview on the situation of the LGBTI community in Lebanon

The situation of the LGBTI individuals in Lebanon is quite hard; frequently the article 534 of the Lebanese Penal law, prohibiting sexual relations that are considered as a contradiction of the laws of nature, is frequently used against this marginalized community and is a flagrant legal backdrop blocking any kind of advocacy campaigns limiting most of the groups and NGOs working on sexual and bodily rights in Lebanon.

On the other hand, LGBTI individuals in Lebanon are being the targets of institutionalized and societal discrimination, social delineation, and legal persecutions in many cases and are often survivors of arbitrary detention and persecution.

In addition, many LGBTI individuals have reported that they have faced discrimination in fields as the medical, educational or even in rural areas.

Note that the fine space of freedom for activism provided in Beirut leave LGBTI individuals outside the capital unassisted, and no adapted services has been offered to these individuals that are mostly from poorer backgrounds which is putting them in a further vulnerability and risks.

Reports and latest incidents reveal clearly the increasing needs for lobbying, and advocating to change perceptions against LGBTI individuals.

Seeing all the unanswered needs, We have decided to come into action; we started in September 2013 as a group of volunteers and worked since then on establishing Proud Lebanon as a nonprofit civil society to work on achieving protection, empowerment & equality to the LGBTI community in Lebanon through community service activities.

  Since it’s first days, Proud Lebanon was dedicated to building a healthy empowered community in Lebanon and the region, where people are effectively empowered to participate in democratic processes that affect their lives and their communities.

To know more about our achievements, please visit our website:www.ProudLebanon.org

frequently the article 534 of the Lebanese Penal law, prohibiting sexual relations that are considered as a contradiction of the laws of nature, is frequently used against this marginalized community and is a flagrant legal backdrop blocking any kind of advocacy campaigns limiting most of the groups and NGOs working on sexual and bodily rights in Lebanon.On the other hand, LGBTI individuals in Lebanon are being the targets of institutionalized and societal discrimination, social delineation, and legal persecutions in many cases and are often survivors of arbitrary detention and persecution.In addition, many LGBTI individuals have reported that they have faced discrimination in fields as the medical, educational or even in rural areas.Note that the fine space of freedom for activism provided in Beirut leave LGBTI individuals outside the capital unassisted, and no adapted services has been offered to these individuals that are mostly from poorer backgrounds which is putting them in a further vulnerability and risks.Reports and latest incidents reveal clearly the increasing needs for lobbying, and advocating to change perceptions against LGBTI individuals.Seeing all the unanswered needs, We have decided to come into action; we started in September 2013 as a group of volunteers and worked since then on establishing Proud Lebanon as a nonprofit civil society to work on achieving protection, empowerment & equality to the LGBTI community in Lebanon through community service activities.  Since it’s first days, Proud Lebanon was dedicated to building a healthy empowered community in Lebanon and the region, where people are effectively empowered to participate in democratic processes that affect their lives and their communities.To know more about our achievements, please visit our website:www.ProudLebanon.org

story: Who? What? And why?
story_txt: Who? What? And why?

story:
Helping At-Risk Children in Guatemala

In Guatemala thousands of children are forced to work on the streets to sell anything they can to help feed their families, while avoiding gang violence and abuse.

 

Programa Valentina & Xennial Digital

A native of Guatemala and now CEO of Xennial Digital, Douglas Fajardo grew up in a challenging environment and is very passionate about helping children from disadvantaged communities. A first-generation migrant from Guatemala to the United States, Douglas understands the pain of leaving loved ones behind and the lack of opportunities for uneducated and unskilled young people. 

For more than a year, Douglas has been working alongside Jessica Hammer, the Co-Founder/CEO of Programa Valentina, to provide at-risk children with technology tools to help close the equity gap, so that they can have the opportunity to get the jobs that will help them achieve a decent life in Guatemala.  

 

Programa Valentina has already trained and certified over 750 young Guatemalans and placed over 300 in professional jobs, but we need to do more and expand the program to help even more deported and at-risk children. 

Douglas and Jessica have worked together to define the plan and resources needed to build a VR Lab with a VR Soft Skills Professional Development Program that will help train these young adults on the key skills they lack and need to thrive in a professional work environment.  

Your contribution will help create a truly impactful program for some of the most disadvantaged children in the world.  The VR Lab will enable us to teach these children the essential social, people and professional skills they need to have access to decent jobs, and in turn provide their families a chance for a better quality of life.  
 

Expanding a Successful Program 

Programa Valentina has been successful because it uses technology to both engage the participants and train them on the skills they need to enter the professional workforce. 

We are looking to raise $90,000  through this campaign to create the VR Lab and augment the work Programa Valentina is doing.  

The funding will be utilized for: 

  1. Hardware Purchase – We are looking to purchase thirty (30) Oculus Quest VR devices, which will be about $20,000 after shipping and import duties. Each Oculus Quest has a cost of $399 plus tax in the US. This will be roughly 22% of the budget. 
  2. Soft Skills Curriculum Development – We have defined four key initial modules to be created: Leadership, Collaboration, Interview Preparation and Public Speaking. The typical cost per module is $35,000 but Xennial Digital will be producing them at much lower cost of $15,000 each. This is about 67% of the budget.  If the campaign receives a surplus of funding, the additional funds will be used to create additional modules. 
  3. Teacher Training – We will need to develop and provide materials for teacher training to ensure the VR Program is successful and well-supported. This will cost about $10,000 or about 11% of the budget since Xennial teams will volunteer most of this time.
     

Why Support this Program 

Valentina welcomes all types of at-risk children to be part of their program, and we need you to join us in this effort to help these young adults in Guatemala.  

People that really want to stop the crisis at the U.S. border know they need to drive economic development and jobs in Latin American countries.  We also know that these caring people want to do more than just provide funding.   

For that reason, the perks we've created for this campaign are designed to allow you to be part of this effort: 

  • You can learn about and meet the kids you will be helping  
  • You can tour the school and meet the teachers at Valentina 

If we don’t make the entire goal, we’ll utilize the funds collected to buy as many headsets as possible and to create as many modules as we can, based on the amount raised.   


The Impact 

Tens of thousands of children in Guatemala have no choice but to be on the street selling whatever they can to provide food and shelter for their families. 

Thousands more are forced to migrate to the United States because of lack of opportunities and education at home, and on their journey through foreign lands they run the risk of being kidnapped, raped, killed, apprehended and, in the best of cases, deported back to Guatemala. 
With your support, you are helping these children build the skills they need to reach their potential and provide their families with the opportunity for a better quality of life. 
 

Our Experience in Guatemala  

During its young life, Programa Valentina has already certified over 750 at-risk children in professional skills and has placed over 300 in professional jobs.  

Xennial_Toto_VR_Education from Xennial Digital on Vimeo.

We know these type of technology tools work with these children, because in May 2018, Xennial Digital partnered with Programa Valentina to donate an educational VR Lab at a rural school in the town of Totonicapan, which is three and half hours from Guatemala City.  

 

The children at Colegio Juan Wesley have not only adopted the technology with ease, but they are enriching their lives by traveling around the world via Google Earth VR and Google Expeditions—opportunities that without VR they would never have. They are also using their VR Lab to help a local community that doesn't have electricity by using a Virtual Reality Circuit Building module to teach locals how to build circuit boards with LED lights, so that they don’t have to use candles in their homes at night. 

Risks & Challenges 

The only hurdle we can envision at this point is that some of the more complex experiences may take more resources than the effort expected. Since our commitment is to help these at-risk children no matter what it takes, we will devote the necessary time and resources needed to complete the program. We will keep the donors of the campaign informed as we reach the different milestones that will be set for the implementation of the program.  

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you are one of the many that believe we need to support economic development in Third-World countries and that technology can help us achieve this goal, we welcome you to our community and our project. 

Tell the world what we’re doing. Share our story with your friends and coworkers who are passionate about our cause just like you! 

We've made it easy for you to share our campaign on all forms of social media.  Whatever is your favorite. Use the Indiegogo share buttons, repost from the Xennial Digital page, write up your own post, or copy the text below. Let’s send a message to the world that we can change the lives of at-risk children and give them the opportunity they deserve for their families and future generations to have a better way of life.

COPY & PASTE TO SOCIAL MEDIA:

Hi friends! Children who are deported from the US back to Guatemala often return to worse conditions than they left, facing violence, extortion and lack of job opportunities. By arming these children with the tools they need to succeed, we can help give their families an opportunity at a better quality of life. 

Check out this campaign to see how a Virtual Reality Lab and Training Program can help these children acquire the skills they need to thrive. Please donate and help spread the word of our Indiegogo campaign:  https://igg.me/at/valentina/emal/20480814

story:
THE POLICE UNFAIRLY TARGETING & HARASSING  THE NJWEEDMAN'S JOINT & SANCTUARY 

"WE ARE UNDER SIEGE"

THE POLITICS OF POT JERSEY STYLE
                                     ----------------------------------------------------------------
One year ago ( May 15th ) We opened the Liberty Bell Temple III as a Temple of Peace & Love. Selling Turkey burgers in our Restaurant called THE JOINT and providing a SANCTUARY in this Government waged Drug war torn community.  Most of this communities problems can be directly traced back to President Nixon's Black Plan (The Controlled Substance Act of 1970). Recently 2/28 the police began harassing us over selling chicken wings after 11pm and we began video taping them and filed a FEDERAL LAWSUIT against them. (3:16 cv 1339) on March 8th, 2016. 
The police refused to accept that we are a temple - a religious organization.

IN RETALIATION for us filing a federal lawsuit against the police The Joint was raided by the police on April 27th, 2016 and stole our camera system and hard drives where we compiled video evidence of the police lying to a federal Judge.

(1) - NJWeedmans bail was $70,000 and Debi his girlfriend and business partner used her mortgage money ($1,800) to set up a payment plan with "Across da street Bailbonds" for 10% of that ($7000). He now owes $5,200 in weekly payments. He really want to get Debi back her $1,800 ASAP! Plz help US.

I DEMAND A SPEEDY INDICTMENT & SPEEDY TRIAL

In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy and public trial, by an impartial jury of the state and district wherein the crime shall have been committed, which district shall have been previously ascertained by law, and to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation; to be confronted with the witnesses against him; to have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his favor, and to have the assistance of counsel for his defense.
This  arrest and raid has caused  tremendous  problems - it has scared  our restaurant customers away. We are  now struggling just to pay rent.  Please help us survive.


- BACK GROUND INFO -

 
On Jan 18th 2010 the State of New Jersey passed into law the Compassionate Use of Marijuana Act of 2010 (CUMMA) which recognized marijuana  as a medicine, which completely contradicts the state's current criminal marijuana statute that defines marijuana as a schedule 1 drug having no medical value. CUMMA is a "secular" exemption to the 2C:-35 criminal statute. 
Knowing that the US Federal Courts ruled if a secular exemption is made; a religious exemption must also be made. ( City of Newark vs Fraternal Order of Police - 170 F.3d 359 (3d Cir. 1999) ) it is clear the State of New Jersey with the passage of CUMMA created a "secular" exemption to the 2C:-35 laws. NJWeedman opened the Liberty Bell Temple III believing this should be protected as a "religious exemption".
The  State of New Jersey has failed to provide a religious exemption  to it's  State 2C:35 criminal marijuana laws even thou it clearly has provided a medical "secular exemption".

                            $10 - buy a Turkey Burger online for a homeless person                     https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PHdA5PXQQ9I

=====================================

The Trentonian, by Penny Ray

The Police are exaggerating!

TRENTON 4/29 - Less than 30 hours after his East State Street businesses were raided by police, Ed Forchion was back at the Joint, rolling a joint and vowing to beat county prosecutors in court.


____________________________________________________

“They just gave me another platform to continue my goal,” Forchion told The Trentonian at 10:30 p.m. Thursday, about two hours after his release from jail. “This is exactly what happened in Burlington County. I beat those prosecutors, and I’ll beat the Mercer County Prosecutor’s Office too. They’re on the wrong side of history.”

Forchion, who’s a marijuana legalization activist known as NJWeedman, was arrested Wednesday along with 10 other people when the county narcotics task force raided his restaurant, sanctuary and tobacco shop, which are adjoined and located across the street from City Hall.

Prosecutors say police confiscated $19,000 worth of marijuana during the raid, and seized cars and cash as suspected proceeds from drug sales. The arrests and seizures were the result of a two-month long investigation, and Forchion was charged with multiple drug possession and distribution offenses.

“It may have been worth a few hundred dollars, but $19,000 worth of weed...are they crazy?” Forchion said. “And distribution? What? They didn’t catch me selling weed to no one. Just about everyone here is a smoker. So yes, there’s weed here. But there’s no distribution going on. They exaggerated big time.”

Forchion said some of the edible marijuana products were leftover from a 420 celebration earlier this month. He also said patrons were scared when they saw cops with rifles, so some of them tossed their bags and Forchion was charged for having them.

“Sharing is part of the weed culture,” Forchion said. “I share because I care, and it’s wrong for them to criminalize that. A lot of people come in here with weed and we share. Sharing is not selling. We’re not running any kind of illegal enterprise out of here.”

In addition to the pot and paraphernalia offenses, Forchion was charged for having five ounces of promethazine on the property, which is a prescription antihistamine normally used to treat allergies and nausea.

“I didn’t even know what promethazine was,” Forchion said. “It turns out that my business partner has a prescription for it and the medicine was here.”

Police also seized his digital video recorder and Weedmobile, Forchion said.

“I’ve been videotaping them, so they took my DVR and charged me for having it,” Forchion said. “They said it’s a crime to have a surveillance system if you’re selling drugs. But we’re not selling drugs. We sell turkey burgers.”

Forchion believes the raid was the latest chapter in an ongoing feud he’s having with politicians who oppose his religious beliefs and views on marijuana legalization.

Forchion is Rastafarian and his religious practices include ritual use of marijuana. He says the paperwork he filed with the state’s division of taxation lists the property between the restaurant and tobacco shop as a “cannabis church.” Forchion believes his church should be allowed to operate 24 hours a day, just as any Baptist church would be allowed to do. After police shut down his religious temple last month for violation of city code, Forchion filed an injunction in federal court to keep it open after 11 p.m.

“This is the politics of pot in New Jersey,” Forchion said. “This is about certain people refusing to accept that I have a church next to my other businesses. One of the police officers even told me the operation wasn’t initiated by the Trenton Police Department. They assisted in the investigation, but it was set in motion by someone else. Politics are in play here.”

Prosecutors said the investigation that led to the raid was sparked by citizen complaints regarding constant foot traffic at the businesses and marijuana being sold from out of the building.

Forchion said he’s “looking forward to the trial,” and that he knows he has the public on his side in regard to marijuana laws.

“I’m a proponent of jury nullification and I’m going to take this to trial,” Forchion said. “Once again I get to publicly argue my case in court and be David fighting the Goliath of government.”


======================================= NJWEEDMAN HOLDS PRESS CONFERENCE TO EXPLAIN HIS SIDE

                  News accounts of this arrest:

(1) - http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2016/04/suspected_pot_sales_at_nj_weedmans_joint_led_to_po.html
(2) - http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2016/04/police_raid_nj_weedmans_joint_in_trenton.html
(3) -  http://nj1015.com/nj-weedman-arrested-with-10-others-as-cops-seize-19k-of-marijuana-from-his-business 
(4) -  http://www.hightimes.com/read/cops-raid-weed-friendly-jersey-eatery-and-church
(5) -   http://www.usnews.com/news/offbeat/articles/2016-04-29/nj-weedman-officials-exaggerated-big-time-in-pot-charges
(6) - https://www.google.com/?gws_rd=ssl#q=njweedman+arrested&tbm=nws

        WE WANT TO  - SURVIVE THE POLICE LIE's

                                                               Please note:
  • THE POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED OUR DVR, because I was recording the police harassing us.
  • THE POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED THE WEEDMOBIL because it was a symbol of my resistance!
  • THE POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED THE JOINTS DELIVERY VEHICLE just to hurt the business.
  • THE POLICE ARE TRYING TO DESTROY OUR TEMPLE because it represents "peace & love" - they thrive off the violence and chaos they create with enforcement of the nations racist drug laws.
  • THIS MONTHS RENT - $3,350 since we opened we have made rent every month except "march" (paid late) when the police began harassing us and now I don't see us making this months rent. -

WE ARE TAKING THIS TO TRIAL UPDATE

Defense Attorney Edward Harrington Heyburn, esq. has agreed to represent us in Federal Court for with the civil case and in state court with the criminal prosecution.

MAY 13th NJWeedman Arrested again For calling Ofc Flowers a Pedophil


DUE TO THE POLICE HARASSMENT many regular customers, patrons and congregation members are staying away. So on May 10th, 2016 NJWeedman stood outside THE JOINT and legally held a sign saying "WE-R-OPEN / FUCK THE POLICE", the Police took offense.

On May 13th in one of the dumbest moves any Police Officer in the nation has ever done, TRENTON POLICE OFFICER HERBERT FLOWERS filed a couple totally bogus charges against  NJWeedman for "CYBER BULLYING & OBSCENE LANGUAGE". 

                                                                           READ THIS
ACLU - SAYS NJWEEDMAN ARREST TOTALLY UNCONSTITUTIONAL
 http://nj1015.com/nj-weedman-arrested-for-calli...

TRENTON 4/29 - Less than 30 hours after his East State Street businesses were raided by police, Ed Forchion was back at the Joint, rolling a joint and vowing to beat county prosecutors in court. 

 
____________________________________________________
“They just gave me another platform to continue my goal,” Forchion told The Trentonian at 10:30 p.m. Thursday, about two hours after his release from jail. “This is exactly what happened in Burlington County. I beat those prosecutors, and I’ll beat the Mercer County Prosecutor’s Office too. They’re on the wrong side of history.”
Forchion, who’s a marijuana legalization activist known as NJWeedman, was arrested Wednesday along with 10 other people when the county narcotics task force raided his restaurant, sanctuary and tobacco shop, which are adjoined and located across the street from City Hall.
Prosecutors say police confiscated $19,000 worth of marijuana during the raid, and seized cars and cash as suspected proceeds from drug sales. The arrests and seizures were the result of a two-month long investigation, and Forchion was charged with multiple drug possession and distribution offenses.


“It may have been worth a few hundred dollars, but $19,000 worth of weed...are they crazy?” Forchion said. “And distribution? What? They didn’t catch me selling weed to no one. Just about everyone here is a smoker. So yes, there’s weed here. But there’s no distribution going on. They exaggerated big time.”
Forchion said some of the edible marijuana products were leftover from a 420 celebration earlier this month. He also said patrons were scared when they saw cops with rifles, so some of them tossed their bags and Forchion was charged for having them.
“Sharing is part of the weed culture,” Forchion said. “I share because I care, and it’s wrong for them to criminalize that. A lot of people come in here with weed and we share. Sharing is not selling. We’re not running any kind of illegal enterprise out of here.”
In addition to the pot and paraphernalia offenses, Forchion was charged for having five ounces of promethazine on the property, which is a prescription antihistamine normally used to treat allergies and nausea.
“I didn’t even know what promethazine was,” Forchion said. “It turns out that my business partner has a prescription for it and the medicine was here.”
Police also seized his digital video recorder and Weedmobile, Forchion said.
“I’ve been videotaping them, so they took my DVR and charged me for having it,” Forchion said. “They said it’s a crime to have a surveillance system if you’re selling drugs. But we’re not selling drugs. We sell turkey burgers.”
Forchion believes the raid was the latest chapter in an ongoing feud he’s having with politicians who oppose his religious beliefs and views on marijuana legalization.
Forchion is Rastafarian and his religious practices include ritual use of marijuana. He says the paperwork he filed with the state’s division of taxation lists the property between the restaurant and tobacco shop as a “cannabis church.” Forchion believes his church should be allowed to operate 24 hours a day, just as any Baptist church would be allowed to do. After police shut down his religious temple last month for violation of city code, Forchion filed an injunction in federal court to keep it open after 11 p.m.
“This is the politics of pot in New Jersey,” Forchion said. “This is about certain people refusing to accept that I have a church next to my other businesses. One of the police officers even told me the operation wasn’t initiated by the Trenton Police Department. They assisted in the investigation, but it was set in motion by someone else. Politics are in play here.”
Prosecutors said the investigation that led to the raid was sparked by citizen complaints regarding constant foot traffic at the businesses and marijuana being sold from out of the building.
Forchion said he’s “looking forward to the trial,” and that he knows he has the public on his side in regard to marijuana laws.
“I’m a proponent of jury nullification and I’m going to take this to trial,” Forchion said. “Once again I get to publicly argue my case in court and be David fighting the Goliath of government.”

=======================================

NJWEEDMAN HOLDS PRESS CONFERENCE TO EXPLAIN HIS SIDE

(2) - http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2016/04/police_raid_nj_weedmans_joint_in_trenton.html

(3) -  http://nj1015.com/nj-weedman-arrested-with-10-others-as-cops-seize-19k-of-marijuana-from-his-business 

(4) -  http://www.hightimes.com/read/cops-raid-weed-friendly-jersey-eatery-and-church

(5) -   http://www.usnews.com/news/offbeat/articles/2016-04-29/nj-weedman-officials-exaggerated-big-time-in-pot-charges

(6) - https://www.google.com/?gws_rd=ssl#q=njweedman+arrested&tbm=nws


        WE WANT TO  - SURVIVE THE POLICE LIE's

                                                               Please note:  THE POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED OUR DVR, because I was recording the police harassing us. THE POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED THE WEEDMOBIL because it was a symbol of my resistance!
THE POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED THE JOINTS DELIVERY VEHICLE just to hurt the business. 
 THE POLICE ARE TRYING TO DESTROY OUR TEMPLE because it represents "peace & love" - they thrive off the violence and chaos they create with enforcement of the nations racist drug laws.
THIS MONTHS RENT - $3,350 since we opened we have made rent every month except "march" (paid late) when the police began harassing us and now I don't see us making this months rent. - 
 
 

WE ARE TAKING THIS TO TRIAL
 UPDATE 

Defense Attorney Edward Harrington Heyburn, esq. has agreed to represent us in Federal Court for with the civil case and in state court with the criminal prosecution. 

MAY 13th NJWeedman Arrested again
 For calling Ofc Flowers a Pedophil


DUE TO THE POLICE HARASSMENT many regular customers, patrons and congregation members are staying away. So on May 10th, 2016 NJWeedman stood outside THE JOINT and legally held a sign saying "WE-R-OPEN / FUCK THE POLICE", the Police took offense. 

On May 13th in one of the dumbest moves any Police Officer in the nation has ever done, TRENTON POLICE OFFICER HERBERT FLOWERS filed a couple totally bogus charges against  NJWeedman for "CYBER BULLYING & OBSCENE LANGUAGE".                                                                             READ THIS


ACLU - SAYS NJWEEDMAN ARREST TOTALLY UNCONSTITUTIONAL http://nj1015.com/nj-weedman-arrested-for-calli...

story:
Update 06/14: For the next two weeks, your contribution will be matched up to a total of $10,000 by a kind donor. You can help us meet the match––and get that much closer to our overall goal––by backing this campaign and sharing it. Thank you!

___

This is a fiercely urgent moment to accelerate movement education and justice work for Palestinian rights. With one click, you can contribute to multiple projects focused on illuminating the root causes of oppression. 

___

LEARN MORE:

A Pivotal Time to Build

In the last few weeks, the cumulative impact of years of education and advocacy work seeded across the movement for Palestinian freedom, justice, and equality has burst forth into public view. We have momentum, and we have to keep going!  Many people, including mainstream figures, are questioning the talking points of the past and moving toward a rights-based narrative for the first time. Palestinians are coming together in joint action, rejecting the fragmentation and labels imposed by the Israeli system. The world is watching for now, but we know from the past that such engagement can be fleeting. Even as we are mourning and responding to the devastating results of this chapter of ongoing Israeli settler colonialism and apartheid, we are planning for the road ahead. We need your steady commitment on this road to justice with us...before the next atrocity. 

Invest in Movement Education 

Right now, people new to our movement are actively seeking out and sharing resources to understand the Palestinian struggle. For years, our movement education work has been helping people teach and learn about the root causes of Palestinian oppression, adopt a vision and language that affirms fundamental rights, and speak out in their communities. Our resources are in especially high demand now and our voices are becoming more important than ever.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Hannah, I m a 21 year old medical student from Switzerland and am currently working as a volunteer for a small NGO called Quick Response Team, QRT in Thessaloniki, Greece. They are partners of the UNICEF.  Here you can check out the website :

http://www.quickresponseteam.gr/en/home-2/

At the moment we visit daily two different refugee camps close to the city of Thessaloniki. In both places live around a 1000 people from many different countries, mainly Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan.  Some of them live in small containers, but daily new people arrive which then live in tents, where it is freezing during the night. This is especially difficult for the families. Daily there is food distribution by the camp but the basic needs of human beings, for hygienic living conditions, medical assistance, and safety are not fulfilled at all. Most children go to school but in the afternoon, there is little to nothing to do, for the children of all ages and especially teenagers. This only contributes to the high vulnerability of this people.

Right now,  NGOs are having great difficulties entering the camps for political reasons, this is the reason why we can only visit the camp site and the people have to come outside. 

We can do little to improve the situation but what we can do is the following: 

Depending on the number of volunteers, we organise creative activities for as many children as possible and involve them in activities that improve the self-esteem and are also fun.

 

 

We also distribute Hygiene materials, like sanitary pads, and for the babies, babybottles, pacifiers and sometimes pampers.

If there are volunteers with a medical background, we also open a small "open-air-clinic", where we simply take care of the small injuries and symptoms of children and women.

Even though it is not much, I still see daily the impact of these small contributions.

For a young woman, one pack of sanitary pads can mean the world for her personal hygiene and dignity.

One babybottle can highly improve the hygienic situation of a small child.

Simply cleaning and taking care of small injuries already helps a lot, so that a small kid doesnt have to go the hospital because of the infection of an itchy mosquito bite.

This is the reason why I ask you, to please donate to this fundraiser, even if the amount you can give is small.

Where does the money go?


Every donation is directly spent to buy simple medications, like Paracetamol, Plasters, Basic Medical Things, Hygiene products like Sanitary pads, baby bottles, or items that we use to organise creative activities with

All this stuff will be directly  bought by us with the money you donate.

I will also update you on what we were able to buy with the money, each week.

story:
Growing up in Ethiopia, I observed the assistance gap for the elderly and those affected by HIV/AIDS. My mother supported her homebound elderly neighbors who were unable to support themselves by sending home-cooked meals once a day and by helping them pay their housing expenses. Once my mother passed, I was inspired to get involved. 

In Ethiopia, there is no organized system to help the elderly or those affected by HIV/AIDS. Many Ethiopians rely on their children for support as they age or become ill. Those without children often end up homeless.  Furthermore, the stigma associated with HIV infected individuals,  affects not only the victims but also everyone in their community. Since this stigma makes it very hard to find and keep jobs, whole families are forced out of their homes. By supporting elderly women and families affected by HIV we are insuring a brighter future for many people . My mom always said "if we at least support the mother, their kids will have a better chance to go to school and secure the future for themselves and their community". That is the underlying goal of this project.

Thanks to your generosity, last year, the Endalech Foundation raised more than $4000 and was able to sponsor 13 families to support their elderly and homebound members. The donations made it possible for the families to pay their rent and relieve some of the financial burdens they carry. In addition, we were able to see to it that their religious and cultural needs and responsibilities were met by helping them celebrate the long awaited and revered holidays of Easter, Christmas. & Ethiopian New Years.

In our Second Annual drive, As we plan to take on more responsibilities to help communities thrive, our donation goal is $12,000. Any amount you donate will better the lives of those who are voiceless in their own community. The people we support may not know each person who donates but they send their gratitude and blessings to all who do. Thank you again for all you have done and all that you will do!

Endalech Foundation team.

story:
• My name is Iyanda Sijuade AKA Frenchaire Gardner (which is Yoruba meaning "Chosen One looking in the Direction of the crown) and I am from Dallas, Texas sustaining in St. Louis, MO.  I am a graduate of Southern Methodist University with degrees in Psychology & Sociology.  I am a victim and survivor of sexual molestation and domestic violence.  With therapy and community support, I am healing from past victimization.
  • My campaign is to raise funds to travel to the exclusive Brooklyn, New York Urban Bush Women's 2017 Summer Leadership Institute July 27th - August 6, 2017.  Purchase t-shirts, food and the St. Louis City permit to march in the streets to Progressive Emporium.  The Ujamaa Group Economics March is civic engagement bringing awareness to how Black people must support Black businesses that vitally educate and empower us.  Thirdly, these funds will allow me to book a venue, microphones and other equipment needed to make my 1st Annual Dance-A-Fun Fundraiser a success.  This family-friendly 4 - 8 hour dance day will be held to bring awareness to the harm of our silence regarding the topics sexual abuse and sex trafficking.
  • As a recent victim of domestic violence and victim blaming, I was fired from a position that I made the most money that I have made in my life.  Dec. 25, 2016, Perrie Gibson AKA Yah Ammi assaulted me and talked himself out of being arrested.  As a result, I took to social media for justice.  5 days later the corporation that I made so much money fired me!  Now I am sorely financially impoverished with Federal, State and local debts.  Your financial gifts will encourage me to keep fighting for social and economic freedom for the African diaspora.  This year, I take further steps toward leading our local communities to trusting each other and working together.  I stand to gain a plethora of skills that will help our community; at this exclusive Urban Bush Women 2017 Summer Leadership Institute.    "('SLI') is our annual 10-day intensive that serves as the foundation for all of UBW’s community engagement activities. SLI builds the global network of community arts practitioners, and what Zollar calls 'front line social justice workers,' by connecting dance professionals and community-based artists in a learning experience that leverages the arts as a vehicle for social activism and civic engagement."   (http://www.urbanbushwomen.org/bold/summer-leadership-institute/)  Give in order that I may travel, lodge and commute to Brooklyn, New York.
  • The Ujamaa Group Economics March being held June 24, 2017 in St. Louis is an extra-curricular event that I am leading.  Inspired by Master Teacher Kaba Kamene Hiawatha AKA Booker T. Coleman, Jr. who told us last summer several action plans to empower, activate the African communities.  Baba Kamene Hiawatha had this to say about this upcoming event:   "When we ask, 'What's our solution?' I say, 'If you want to March, March to the nearest American African owned store and spend $25...Buyout Black Businesses. Congratulations to the Ujamaa Group Economics March!!!  Can you imagine what would happen if this concept spread throughout the African community? Keep on Keepin' On. It ain't over 'til we win. Kaba Hiawatha” These funds will allow me to purchase the needed St. Louis City permit to march in the streets; t-shirts and food for after we march and socialize at Progressive Emporium.
  • Lastly, I am hosting a fundraiser to raise awareness about sexual abuse and molestation.  I was molested by my father as a child and that had lasting effects on me.  We do not talk about the prevalence of family molestation, sexual abuse and sex trafficking in detail enough.  In this world, we know people are being molested and sex trafficked but we aren't having hard conversations about it.  This dance event stands to discuss how prevalent sexual abuse and trafficking are in our local communities.  Being molested by the person, who was supposed to protect me from abusers, had a lasting effect on my life and personal relationships.  This event will be fun, coed and family friendly because I always want the youth involved.  The desire is to book a venue, rent microphones, stages, hire a DJ and other things to produce this dance event to arrest sexual abuse and trafficking.

:

  • Hoping to raise at least $7,000.  $2,000 of the money will purchase my round-trip airplane tickets to Brooklyn, New York July 27th - Aug. 6th; rent a hotel room, rent a rental car, purchase food and any other necessary items for the Urban Bush Women's 2017 Summer Leadership Institute.
    • $1,500 of the funds raised here will purchase the St. Louis City permit needed to march in the streets June 24th.  Purchase the event t-shirts and buy food for the marchers to eat after we have spent our $25 each.
    • The rest of the money ($3,500) will be spent planning the First Annual Dance-A-Fun to arrest sexual abuse and trafficking.  I can book a large of enough venue space for at least 500, women, men and women to dance for 4 - 8 hours.  It's important that we exercise at least 30 minutes a day to remain healthy and heart healthy.  Dance is great cardio.  Your children get to dance with you and watch you have fun.  This event's cause is arresting sexual abuse and trafficking.  At the ALIVE & Well STL Trauma Training this year I learned that if you have experience at least 1 traumatic event as a child, that event increases the likelihood that you will experience a traumatic event as an adult.
      • 1 in 5 girls and 1 in 20 boys is a victim of child sexual abuse;
      • Self-report studies show that 20% of adult females and 5-10% of adult males recall a childhood sexual assault or sexual abuse incident;
      • During a one-year period in the U.S., 16% of youth ages 14 to 17 had been sexually victimized;
      • Over the course of their lifetime, 28% of U.S. youth ages 14 to 17 had been sexually victimized;
      • Children are most vulnerable to CSA between the ages of 7 and 13. Source:  Child Sexual Abuse Statistics https://victimsofcrime.org/media/reporting-on-child-sexual-abuse/child-sexual-abuse-statistics

 

  • Will ship 4 ounces of Nigerian organic shea butter to those who choose this perk late Fall after recovering from the summer's events.
  • If I do not reach the $7,000 goal, I will use the funds to buy food for the upcoming Ujamaa Group Economics March being held in St. Louis, Missouri June 24th, 2017.   And I will buy my flight, rental car, lodging and any other expenses that I may incur in Brooklyn New York when I participate in Urban Bush Women's 2017 Summer Leadership Institute July 27th - August 6, 2017.
  • These 3 events are not just for me.  Communities stand to gain from my experiences and these planned events.  It truly takes a village to raise a child.  It truly takes a village to trust, care and share with each other to ensure that our survival happens.  By you giving to me, I will gain proper skills to engage the local communities and African diaspora.  My plan is to use the arts to engage the community to love and trust each other again.
  • I have a track record of engaging and supporting local organizations that strengthen our communities such as Hands Up United, Solidarity Economy STL, St. Louis Pan Afrikan Movement, The Black Tax Collective, Better Family Life, Inc., Triune International Service Organization, Moving4ward Ministries, Inc., Chosen for Change, The Michael Brown Chosen for Change Foundation, Tauheed Youth Group and more.
  • As a result of being assaulted last year, I was fired from the position where I'd made the most money in my life.  The financial setbacks are great.  I am in a lot of debt.  But I press on towards the mark of the HIGH calling of empowering and building strong economic and educational African institutions in the diaspora but especially in St. Louis, Missouri.  I need your help to keep going.

I tried raising money for a lawyer a few years ago before my 4 children were adopted.  The fundraiser was unsuccessful maybe because I was not very open and transparent about what I was experiencing.  Today, I am more mature and accepting of my life's experiences.  Therefore, I know that my life’s challenges not only molded me to be the leader that I am but will also inspire others.  Some challenges maybe in getting this campaign to the right compassionate people in the world who are willing to share their resources with another person that cares.

I am an overcomer and survivor of lots of traumatic victimization. But I stand today, willing to share my life with you for the greater good.  I will be sharing this campaign link every place that I can think of and I hope that you will give and do the same.

Your gifts great and small are appreciated and encouraged but some will not be able to give and that is ok.  For those of you unable to give, PLEASE SHARE THE CAMPAIGN LINK WITH YOUR FAMILIES AND PEERS ON ALL OF YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA OUTLETS. USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARING TOOLS.

 

THANK YOU FOR EVERY GIFT.

Hoping to raise at least $7,000.  $2,000 of the money will purchase my round-trip airplane tickets to Brooklyn, New York July 27th - Aug. 6th; rent a hotel room, rent a rental car, purchase food and any other necessary items for the Urban Bush Women's 2017 Summer Leadership Institute.
$1,500 of the funds raised here will purchase the St. Louis City permit needed to march in the streets June 24th.  Purchase the event t-shirts and buy food for the marchers to eat after we have spent our $25 each.
The rest of the money ($3,500) will be spent planning the First Annual Dance-A-Fun to arrest sexual abuse and trafficking.  I can book a large of enough venue space for at least 500, women, men and women to dance for 4 - 8 hours.  It's important that we exercise at least 30 minutes a day to remain healthy and heart healthy.  Dance is great cardio.  Your children get to dance with you and watch you have fun.  This event's cause is arresting sexual abuse and trafficking.  At the ALIVE & Well STL Trauma Training this year I learned that if you have experience at least 1 traumatic event as a child, that event increases the likelihood that you will experience a traumatic event as an adult.
1 in 5 girls and 1 in 20 boys is a victim of child sexual abuse;

Self-report studies show that 20% of adult females and 5-10% of adult males recall a childhood sexual assault or sexual abuse incident;
During a one-year period in the U.S., 16% of youth ages 14 to 17 had been sexually victimized;
Over the course of their lifetime, 28% of U.S. youth ages 14 to 17 had been sexually victimized;

Children are most vulnerable to CSA between the ages of 7 and 13. Source:  Child Sexual Abuse Statistics https://victimsofcrime.org/media/reporting-on-child-sexual-abuse/child-sexual-abuse-statistics





 

Will ship 4 ounces of Nigerian organic shea butter to those who choose this perk late Fall after recovering from the summer's events.
If I do not reach the $7,000 goal, I will use the funds to buy food for the upcoming Ujamaa Group Economics March being held in St. Louis, Missouri June 24th, 2017.   And I will buy my flight, rental car, lodging and any other expenses that I may incur in Brooklyn New York when I participate in Urban Bush Women's 2017 Summer Leadership Institute July 27th - August 6, 2017.


These 3 events are not just for me.  Communities stand to gain from my experiences and these planned events.  It truly takes a village to raise a child.  It truly takes a village to trust, care and share with each other to ensure that our survival happens.  By you giving to me, I will gain proper skills to engage the local communities and African diaspora.  My plan is to use the arts to engage the community to love and trust each other again.
I have a track record of engaging and supporting local organizations that strengthen our communities such as Hands Up United, Solidarity Economy STL, St. Louis Pan Afrikan Movement, The Black Tax Collective, Better Family Life, Inc., Triune International Service Organization, Moving4ward Ministries, Inc., Chosen for Change, The Michael Brown Chosen for Change Foundation, Tauheed Youth Group and more.
As a result of being assaulted last year, I was fired from the position where I'd made the most money in my life.  The financial setbacks are great.  I am in a lot of debt.  But I press on towards the mark of the HIGH calling of empowering and building strong economic and educational African institutions in the diaspora but especially in St. Louis, Missouri.  I need your help to keep going.

I tried raising money for a lawyer a few years ago before my 4 children were adopted.  The fundraiser was unsuccessful maybe because I was not very open and transparent about what I was experiencing.  Today, I am more mature and accepting of my life's experiences.  Therefore, I know that my life’s challenges not only molded me to be the leader that I am but will also inspire others.  Some challenges maybe in getting this campaign to the right compassionate people in the world who are willing to share their resources with another person that cares.
I am an overcomer and survivor of lots of traumatic victimization. But I stand today, willing to share my life with you for the greater good.  I will be sharing this campaign link every place that I can think of and I hope that you will give and do the same.
Your gifts great and small are appreciated and encouraged but some will not be able to give and that is ok.  For those of you unable to give, PLEASE SHARE THE CAMPAIGN LINK WITH YOUR FAMILIES AND PEERS ON ALL OF YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA OUTLETS. USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARING TOOLS.
 
THANK YOU FOR EVERY GIFT.

story:
H2Ouse

We are the POP Warriors from Prince of Peace Christian School in Carrolton TX and we’re participating in the First Lego League robotics competition. This season, we were challenged to improve the way people find, transport, use, or dispose of water.

Last summer, Connor visited Thailand. While driving through the poor areas, he noticed that the people were wearing dirty, rugged clothing and torn up sandals. It really changed the way he saw the world, and he wanted to help the people who were living those conditions.

When Connor told the team his story, it touched all of our hearts and then we too wanted to help the poor people.

So, the team decided to incorporate refugees with this year’s water project.

The problem that we decided to solve was the lack of clean water in the refugee camps in Bangladesh or other surrounding areas that are populated by the people from Myanmar.

In these camps, the residents have to walk for miles to get to their water that comes from muddy lakes. They have to bathe, drink, cook, and wash their belongings in the same source of water every day. As you can imagine, there are tons of diseases in these camps because of the poor conditions these people are living in.

Other ways that people have solved this problem are to drill wells, setup rain collecting barrels, provide filters, or deliver bottled water, which is too expensive and dangerous.

 Our solution is called H2Ouse. H2Ouse is better because it provides shelter, as well as a renewable water source. It also saves the refugee's from having to walk miles to get their water.

With cleaner water, we can help decrease the chance of catching diseases, and help the refugees live a happier and healthier life.

We are planning to use stackable plastic water storage bricks to build a shelter that catches rain. H2Ouse will be a safe way to store water, unlike dirty, unclean, water storage. It will improve their everyday life by not drinking out of the same water they bathe in.

There is a water brick commercially available that is used store water. We plan to modify the design to allow the water to drain from brick to brick. The plastic we will use to produce the bricks will be infused with a tiny amount of silver and magnesium to help control bacteria. They'll be similar in size and construction, and we think it will be about the same cost to produce.

We plan to build a working 3D scale model of what H2Ouse will look like. It will be a 1/5 scale model of the H2Ouse which is six feet wide, nine feet long, and six feet high. We'll be using the water bricks, bamboo, and tarp to make the actual shelter. The bamboo is naturally found in the location of the camps. H2Ouse will hold about 700 gallons of clean water that can be used for cooking, cleaning, and drinking.  

Weatherbase.com says that the average rainfall in Bangladesh is about 10 in. per month. We've calculated that in the rainy months, we will collect up to 1200 gallons of water in each shelter. According to The UN Refugee Agency, the average refugee needs around 5 gallons of water per day to survive. This means the average family of four needs about 600 gallons to survive each month.

Based off the cost of the commercially available water bricks, we believe that the manufacturing price will be about $4.00 per brick. It'll take about 200 bricks to build 1 shelter.

 1 complete H2Ouse will fit on two standard palates, and 20 shelters will fit in a standard 40ft ISO shipping container. We've determined that it will cost $575.00 to ship a container over sea.

 The total cost of a manufactured and delivered shelter from Shanghai to Bangladesh is around $870.00 and it is possible that we can reduce that cost if we are able to locally manufacture them.

We think it will take about three hours for two people to build one H2Ouse. We visited the International Rescue Committee and we learned what stagnate water is and we learned more about what it's like to live in a refugee camp and how the refugees receive their water. We also talked to a professional blow molder and learned how blow molding works, how the process happens, and how we can locally manufacture the water bricks.

In conclusion, we believe that we can help change the lives of the refugees from Myanmar in Bangladesh. But, H2Ouse can also be used in other tropical areas other than Bangladesh. We know that these H2Ouse don't solve every problem in refugee camps, but we know that these water brick houses can be very helpful for the refugees to get clean water and a suitable shelter to live in.

Our Goal

Our goal is to raise at least $6,250 dollars to help create a working 3D scale model of the H2Ouse.

If we can't raise enough money, our first option is to buy our own small 3D printer which will be less expensive, but will take six months to print the model. We think that for this to work, we will have to have raised at least $2000. If we don't reach at least $2000, then our second option is to donate the money to the IRC, a company that helps support refugees. We will test the concept of water filling up in the bricks, as well as the ability of the bricks to control bacteria. 

How You can Make a Difference

  • You can donate at least $25 to pay for one or more bricks
  • Like and Share this campaign!

Risks and Challenges

  • A challenge we will face is having to learn how to draw our model in Sketch Up
  • A risk that we have is having the model not work properly

Solutions

  • One of our teammates named Spencer has already started to learn how to draw in Sketch Up
  • We can print out two bricks and see if they fit together. If they do, then we will print out the rest of the bricks. If they don't then we will re design the model until they do fit.

Thanks for Reading! :D

You can donate at least $25 to pay for one or more bricks

A challenge we will face is having to learn how to draw our model in Sketch Up
A risk that we have is having the model not work properly

Solutions

Thanks for Reading! :D

story:
http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/lakota-m...

"Ówaŋžila s'e wówaši ečhúŋk'uŋpi" -We work in unity

A national team of professional Native entrepreneurs, academics, athletes, and community organizers have come together to make the Lakota Dream Project a reality. We have found the land, designed the building, and have developed different components of cultural, social and educational programs that meet the immediate needs of the surrounding community. Now we are raising $6 million dollars to purchase the land and to build the museum. 

The money raised from this campaign will go to covering the initial costs of the Lakota Dream Project, providing an opportunity for meaningful collective action during a period when sacred sites, lands and territories of Indigenous peoples are under continued threat. The Lakota Dream Project will serve as a model for addressing the multi-generational impacts of the destruction and theft of these artifacts by ensuring that they are properly preserved in a state of the art museum, not as artifacts of history, but as part of the living heritage of Indigenous peoples.

____________________________________________________________________________

Prayer- Grandfather, as I sit here writing this I am emotional with tears wanting to fall. Thinking to myself, how do I get people to believe in this project? How do I meet the professional credibility to beg people to open their heart and be kind? Grandfather, where would I be without you. Why am I doing this project knowing how large this is, knowing that it is going to take my whole life and I will most likely die with my whole life dedicated to this project. Im doing it because of you. Because my Lakota way of life is where my heart lies. That little boy who would talk to you and say “for one time I want to be a sun-dancer and pray for my people”. You not only let that little boy fulfill what his heart told him to do. You showed him you are pure and good. You showed him if you suffer for your people, you will actually live. Grandfather, I have nothing more to give or to chase, I have given my life to you, because you have given me a life money or fame cannot buy. Grandfather, I will always be that little boy with purity, and no sense in how cold the world can be. Whether this project means the same to somebody else or not, I will die trying for it. Because, that little boy is somewhere out there and he is going to love you like I love you.

-Mitakuye Oyasin

čhaŋšká upíǧi (Red Tail Hawk)

čhaŋnúŋpa (Sacred Pipe)

____________________________________________________________________________

Mission Statement

Providing an accurate interpretation of The Great Plains tribes through documented resources, artifacts and local historians with the intention to instill knowledge, strong sense of identity, and hope into the Lakota and all Native people.

A national team of professional entrepreneurs, academics, athletes, and community organizers have come together to make the Lakota Dream Project a reality. We have found the land, designed the building, and have developed different components of cultural, social and educational programs that meet the immediate needs of the surrounding community. Now we are raising $6 million dollars to purchase the land and to build the museum.

Lakota Dream has access to artifacts that need to come home.

The sacred Black Hills will become the new home for the museum, within close proximity of the region’s largest tourist attractions: Mt. Rushmore Memorial and Crazy Horse Memorial. These ancestral lands are deeply woven into the blood lines of millions of Lakota people who have never ceded their rightful ownership of the Black Hills upheld by the Ft. Laramie Treaty of 1868. The museum and monument will be a physical reminder to restore hope and promote healing for all Native people, as the first Indigenous-led museum that highlights the proud history of Lakota people and other Great Plain Tribes from their own lens. The Museum and monument will showcase the deep history connected to the region, as well as the legacy of survival and cultural resiliency of a Peoples’ that have overcome generational trauma, genocidal and forced assimilation policies.

The museum will be structured to showcase and preserve artifacts that are already in possession of the Lakota Sioux tribes and those that are going through the repatriation process. This is an important and necessary function as the Great Plain Tribes do not have appropriate places to store and protect these priceless artifacts.

____________________________________________________________________________

About (NAGPRA)

The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA) was enacted November 16th , 1990. Its purpose was to establish tribal ownership of cultural items either discovered or excavated (from archaeological excavation) on federal or tribal land (public not private land). NAGPRA states that Native American human remains and the associated funerary objects belong to lineal descendants. If lineal descendants cannot be identified (i.e. culturally unidentifiable objects) then the remains and objects, along with sacred and funerary objects and objects of cultural patrimony belong to the tribe whose land the objects and remains were found or they belong to the tribe having the closest known relationship to them. The process of returning our ancestors and our objects is called repatriation. In order for ancestors and objects to come home, museums and institutions will either contact the tribe directly or the tribe can contact that museum or institution who may have objects or ancestors. A consultation meeting is then scheduled in order for both entities to see the objects or ancestors in question. After consultation, the repatriation process can begin. Once ancestors or items are returned, the tribe can then choose to do with them what they wish. If there are objects or ancestors found in an archaeological excavation then the tribe should be notified and reburial or repatriation can begin. By creating an institution such as Lakota Dream Museum it makes it easier for Lakota and Great Plains ancestors and objects to be returned to the community. A museum that is run for and by Lakota people will allow the museum to facilitatethe repatriation process, taking the burden (financial, spiritual and emotional) away from individual tribal members. 
-Emily C. Van Alst Ph.D. (Lakota Dream Currator)

____________________________________________________________________________

Lakota Dream Museum & Monument

Indigenous Peoples have long been denied their histories, their traditional territories, and access to thousands of their sacred sites. The Lakota Dream Museum and Monument aims to be the first Native owned and operated museum and cultural education center that will facilitate the return and long-term protection of sacred artifacts that were stolen or otherwise unjustly taken from Indigenous Peoples. As the only museum of its kind, we will honor the living memories of Indigenous peoples by providing cultural, social, and educational programs grounded in the oral traditions and traditional knowledge systems unique to their communities.

The first Native owned museum that will enable the return of precious artifacts to the Lakota people and other great plain tribes, bringing to life the histories, cultural knowledge, and ancestral experiences to educate future generations.

____________________________________________________________________________

Program Elements

  • Exhibit Space
  • Theater
  • Exhibit Storage
  • Library/Archive
  • Food Court
  • Offices
  • Youth Room
  • Amphitheater
  • Restrooms
  • Event Room
  • Classrooms

Lakota Dream will be a 20,000 SF building with room to grow in the future.

____________________________________________________________________________

The Land, why is this location important?

Sitting Bull Crystal Caverns- This location was the center place of many ceremonies performed by Lakota Holy-man Black Elk. Many of our people used the caves found on this land to stay warm during the harsh winters. It is said that this was one of Sitting Bulls last stops before the Battle of Little Big Horn. 

https://lakotadream.org/about/pdf/land.pdf

____________________________________________________________________________

Our ancestors are always here watching over us, all you have to do is look.

____________________________________________________________________________

Programs under Lakota Dream

  • Lakota Language Revitalization Program
  • Educational Support Program
  • Internships
  • Suicide Prevention Program
  • Workforce Development Program
  • Small Business Loans
  • Lakota Dream Educational Scholarships
  • Therapy through Arts and Crafts Program
  • Ceremonial/Traditional Teachings Program

____________________________________________________________________________

My boy, you are going to walk a hard life. Be strong, there is no turning back.

____________________________________________________________________________

Lakota Dreams Prayer.

____________________________________________________________________________

Media

http://www.lakotacountrytimes.com/news/2018-02-01/Front_Page/Museum_About_Lakota_People_By_Lakota_People_In_The.html

http://www.sdpb.org/blogs/kevinwoster/oglala-yo...

story:
We must stop believing the problems are too big, and that we are too small.

Since 2010, The Peace Project has mobilized creatives worldwide to collaborate on bold humanitarian efforts that have changed over 10,000 lives. Projects include distribution of 10,000 pairs of crutches across Sierra Leone on World Peace Day 2011, design of a Peace Museum with the UN, and the master planning & rebuilding of a community in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan: 40 custom-designed “instant” houses, plus a community center.

We begin projects by asking “Where can we make the biggest difference?” Now, our sights are set on Israel/Palestine where peace seems further away than ever.  Our work has shown us that the one sure way to bring peace closer is to amplify the work of grassroots visionaries via the resources of our diverse international network of creators.

Non-violence is the art of being human.

Born as a refugee to a political family, Ali Abu Awwad was arrested as a teenager during the First Intifada and spent four years in an Israeli prison where he learned about non-violence while studying the lives of Nelson Mandela, Martin Luther King and Mahatma Gandhi.  After being released due to the Oslo Accord, Ali was badly wounded and his brother violently killed during the Second Intifada.  A fortuitous meeting with Israelis who had also lost loved ones in the conflict, set the stage for the founding of Roots.

Peace is where opposing truths can fit together in one place.

In 2014, Ali was instrumental in bringing together two groups who would normally never meet -- Palestinian activists and Israeli rabbis from the settlements in the West Bank. Inspired by the transformation that occurred with interaction and dialogue, they co-founded Roots and began the courageous work of finding common ground and forging a way towards equal rights, justice and prosperity on the land both feel a deep connection to.

Shortly after founding Roots, Ali began building Karama (meaning dignity) Center on the land his family has owned for four generations. Karama is in Area C which accounts for nearly 60% of the West Bank’s land. Under Israeli control, upwards of 500,000 Israelis live in 125 settlements and 100 outposts.  Israel is constantly building here, but it is virtually prohibited for Palestinians which makes the creation of Karama Center even more remarkable.

The Peace Project will work hand-in-hand with Ali and a team of designers, architects and local tradesmen to master plan and transform the existing utilitarian buildings into a holistic campus where peace initiatives and healing work can thrive.  Karama Center will express the richness of Palestinian heritage and culture, and inspire international visitors (currently 500 - 700 per week) to believe peace is achievable.  Arts & Crafts from Palestine’s rich pool of talent will be showcased and sold to visitors to help sustain local artisans, fund Karama, and spread the message of unity once visitors return home from the Holy Land.

Timing is everything.

Peace is in short supply in the Holy Land. Help us fast-track changing hearts and minds and creating a bridge between Israelis and Palestinians.  Phase I has already been successfully completed and we're scheduled to implement Phase II in August with completion of all work by November 2019.  Phase II includes constructing the entrance to the center, renovating the kitchen and replacing the restrooms so that they can be used by daily visitors and overnight lodgers.  Phase III includes renovation of all of the meeting rooms and landscaping of the grounds.

Money isn't everything, but everything needs money.

Movements like The Peace Project and the organizations Ali founded, Roots and Taghyeer, rely on the power of people coming together across borders to share their unique talents and resources so that our collective vision of equal rights and justice can be brought into view.

Help fund the transformation of the Karama Center by planting a seed of hope in your heart and making a donation or purchasing a perk that has been given with love and intention by the community of artists who have supported The Peace Project's work since 2010.

NOTE:  We'll be adding perks throughout this campaign, so pick one up now and then check back in a few days to see what's new.

We make a living by what we get.  We make a life by what we give.

Peace. Salaam. Shalom.
story_txt:
We must stop believing the problems are too big, and that we are too small.
Since 2010, The Peace Project has mobilized creatives worldwide to collaborate on bold humanitarian efforts that have changed over 10,000 lives. Projects include distribution of 10,000 pairs of crutches across Sierra Leone on World Peace Day 2011, design of a Peace Museum with the UN, and the master planning & rebuilding of a community in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan: 40 custom-designed “instant” houses, plus a community center.

We begin projects by asking “Where can we make the biggest difference?” Now, our sights are set on Israel/Palestine where peace seems further away than ever.  Our work has shown us that the one sure way to bring peace closer is to amplify the work of grassroots visionaries via the resources of our diverse international network of creators.
Non-violence is the art of being human.

story:
Overview

Fandom Forward is dedicating ourselves to showing up for immigrants, fighting for the climate, engaging emerging activists, and much more. 2021 is a year of re-birth for the organization, so we're using today as a change to explore our vault of vintage items, campaign knick knacks, and other lost treasures for supporters to explore and bring home today!

For 16 years, we’ve proven the power of story to inspire and drive change. Today, dark forces tell stories designed to drive fear, hate, and hopelessness, but Fandom Forward is helping to mobilize fans to imagine and create a better story - one grounded in leadership, love, and equality for all.  

The Power of Story

Fandom Forward is a game-changing, innovative organization that uses the power of pop culture to transform fans into activists. We bring community organizing to online and offline fan spaces and channel fans’ creativity, passion, and critical thinking into making real world change. By pivoting people to action using the stories they already love, Fandom Forward provides fun, hopeful ways for fans to become long-term activists. 

Our method is working: Fandom Forward has over 100 chapters and 90K members in all 50 U.S. states and 30 countries. These members are largely young women and LGBTQIA+ folks, and nearly 60% had never before been involved in activism prior to joining Fandom Forward! In the last year, Fandom Forward has trained nearly 2,000 emerging activists, engaged over 100,000 first-time voters, launched three new virtual conferences for fan activists, and led dozens of actions for climate justice, immigrant rights, and trans rights!

In 2021 and 2022, we're planning big things: two new campaigns around mental health and abolition, a new supportive coaching program for our Chapter Organizers, and the launch of the first ever coalition for fan organizers (in partnership with Black Girls Create and Pop Culture Collaborative)! Dive into our past and help support our future!

story:
What is Human Refugees?

Dear Friends,

Human Refugees is an immersive exhibition event taking place from 12pm - 8pm on July 12th - 14th in London. We will be showing documentaries, photographs, artwork, and information depicting a refugee's journey. Upon arrival at the event, guests will join a tour that will guide them through the event space. Each tour will last approximately an hour and Middle-Eastern food will be served at the end. Guests are invited to make the experience as interactive as possible and ask any questions they have on the crisis to the guide accompanying them.

Who We Are

We are a group of international artists, journalists, refugees and asylum seekers who have all developed a strong interest in social issues, particularly the refugee crisis. Most of us are London based, though some of us reside in the Middle East. Our curator, Miholyn Soon, has spent the past two years cultivating an ever-expanding passion and knowledge on the issue, having spent time with refugees in camps in France, Germany and most recently, Lebanon.

Our Aim

Our aim with Human Refugees is to help engage the public more with the issue, address some of its misconceptions and stimulate ideas on how people can help those affected. We want to create a safe space where people of differing views can come together and discuss the crisis, no matter their stance. We hope that a more inclusive approach to the issue will allow the public to come together and push for more effective and humane solutions for the people caught up in this huge crisis.

Why This Event Is Important

Millions of people on Earth right now are refugees, searching for a way forward. We believe more could be done to help these people on their journeys. We feel the refugee crisis is an issue that is not engaged with enough. No matter your opinion, we believe everyone can come to an agreement that it is a huge problem, not just for Europe, but on a global scale. We are facing one of the largest refugee crises in history. The problem is, there are too many conflicting opinions on the matter which hinder progress being made. Many people only get their information about it through the media, so few people have a well-rounded understanding of what is really happening. We believe this event will give people the opportunity to engage in a way they usually don’t. We hope it inspires them to approach the issue differently. 

We Need Your Help

We want this event to be the best it can be. We know it has potential, but in order to fulfil that potential, we need to raise some funds to bring this plan to life. Please help us reach our target budget of £3,500.

Where Your Money Will Go

This money will go into funding the physical materials needed to build each installation, electronic and building equipment, security for the venue, public liability insurance, transport costs, and printing the many flyers, posters and photography & information boards. 

What You Get

Besides the satisfaction of helping us realise this important event, when you contribute to our crowdfunding campaign you can choose between a selection of perks. For higher donations, you will receive a booklet that details all the installations, artwork and interviews that comprise our event, as well as further information. You can also be rewarded by receiving a large poster or a complimentary Palestinian dish upon attending the event.

Other Ways You Can Help

You don't have to contribute financially to help us achieve our mission. 

  • Spread the word about our crowdfunding campaign to your friends, community and networks.
  • Click here to visit our Facebook event - please click "Attending" or "Interested" and invite your friends to the event. 
  • Like and Share our Human Refugees Facebook page by clicking here.
  • Follow us on Twitter @HumanRefugees by clicking here.
  • Like, retweet and share our social media posts to help us reach as many friends, family and acquaintances as possible.

All these actions will help us achieve our mission of bringing people together to engage more with this important issue and bring about change.
