story:
The LGTBQ+ Youth Legislative Theatre Project is civic engagement at its best with a creative twist: employing interactive theatre to directly impact policy change on a local as well as potentially state and national levels.
Your voice is needed in this practice of true democracy!

The Mandala Center for Change proudly launches this project aimed at public education and social change around the issues faced by LGTBQ+ youth – an underrepresented population, especially on government and policy-making levels. Legislative Theatre has been effectively used to steer laws and policies around the world.  Inclusive, fun, dynamic and participatory!


LEGISLATIVE THEATRE: A THREE-STEP PROCESS

1 - The project kicks off this August 2017 with a 5-day Theatre of the Oppressed (TO) workshop for 20 youth (ages 14-20), who self-identify as LGBTQ+. Participants will be guided by Marc Weinblatt, a world-renowned TO facilitator and founder of the Mandala Center, and assisted by Tanner DeLuna, a youth leader, activist, and emerging TO practitioner. The youth will explore their struggles through dynamic creative processes and identify real threats to themselves and their community. 

2 - Through personal story sharing youth will create a short play depicting their real-life struggles. This play will be presented in two interactive theatre performances for the general public and invited legislators/policy makers on September 25 & 26, 2017. 

Each performance will include a community forum where audience members come on stage to take over a character and improvise solutions to the issues presented by the youth.

3 - Finally both youth and audience will propose policy ideas and vote on the laws they want to see passed in a theatrical mock legislature. Legislators and other policy makers who have the power to create the change will see and hear first-hand the problems faced by the youth and the community’s solutions to address them.


THE ROOTS OF LEGISLATIVE THEATRE

Developed by Brazilian visionary and Nobel Prize nominee, Augusto Boal, Legislative Theatre is part of his famous Theatre of the Oppressed (TO). TO is used all over the world for social and political activism, conflict resolution, community building, therapy, and government legislation. It is practiced globally on a grassroots level by community organizers, activists, teachers, social workers, cultural animators, and more.

The Mandala Center for Change, along with its founder, Marc Weinblatt, is one of the most experienced and long-standing hubs for the training and grassroots practice of Theatre of the Oppressed in the world. Founded in 1999, the Mandala Center is a multi-disciplinary arts education organization dedicated to community dialogue, social justice, and societal transformation.


RIPPLES OF IMPACT

Not only will this project cultivate a way for LGBTQ+ youth to bond and express their experiences in a supportive, safe space; it will create a platform for the local community and its legislators to directly change laws -- youth, adults, allies, and policy-makers working together.

It also gives youth an opportunity to participate in a true democratic process and an experiential knowledge of how the legislative process works.

And we know it works...because of the success of Mandala Center’s previous Legislative Theatre projects: Youth Legislative Theatre project in Clallam County, WA on the failure of the education system (2016) and our Legislative Theatre project on Healthcare Access and Affordability in Jefferson County, WA (2015).

Take it from the Jefferson County Hospital Commissioner, in office 44 years, Anthony DeLeo:

"This was the most effective community dialogue on healthcare I have ever attended."
 

YOUR MONEY AT WORK FOR SOCIAL CHANGE

The success of this project depends on the support of individuals like you. The youth are ready to dive in, the facilitators are eager to begin, grant proposals are being written, PR is underway, legislators are being contacted... now it's your turn to get involved and support grassroots social change driven by the voices of creative, powerful young people and their allies.

Your financial contribution will support a percentage of our $12,000 budget. Along with basics like administrative costs, facilitator fees, production costs, and marketing materials, we are also dedicated to providing youth stipends, food for participants during the project, and an accessible public venue for two evenings of Legislative Theatre performances so anyone who is interested in supporting this issue can attend.
 

It is time for unheard voices to be expressed. It is time for policy-makers to listen. Join us and make this exploration a call to action!
Thank you for your support.

story:
My name is Charles King.  I am a Marine and Iraq veteran.  My wife (who majored in non-profit business management) and I are working together to create a non-profit to permanently house homeless/nearly homeless veterans.  We see a need for this as most current methods for housing veterans seem to only be temporary, and none address underlying issues that cause homelessness.  We believe that veterans are not given the time they need to deal and learn to live with issues they encounter on a day to day basis.  Our goal is to give them this time so that they can work on themselves.  We think that giving this time to them will eventually allow them to live a life they want to live, instead of going through the motions, and just existing.
      We are developing this non-profit from the ground up and are currently looking for the funds to incorporate and file for 501 (c)(3) status.  Once we have achieved this, we will be crowd-sourcing a seed money campaign, as well as contacting local and nationwide businesses about fundraising.  The funds obtained for the non-profit will go toward acquiring land, equipment, and supplies to permanently house these veterans. 
     The impact these funds will have are exponential.  By being able to positively impact the underlying issues of homelessness and suicides amongst veterans, we will give them a second chance at life, and allow them to make positive impacts on others with the skills and experiences they have obtained while in the military. 
    
     The risks and challenges we face are obtaining the 501 (c)(3) status and acquiring land in an area that supports self-sufficient living styles.  We believe that with proper funding and legal counsel, obtaining 501 (c)(3) status will not be difficult.  We have also seen where eco-villages have overcome the obstacles and restrictions in nearby local municipalities, and we will be actively seeking their assistance in this area.
    For our initial campaign, we are asking that people donate anything they can, as every dollar helps.  We also understand that times are tight, and if they can't donate that they can still help us and the veterans we want to help.  Just through Facebook alone, if I have 20 friends who share this mission, and each of them have 20, and so on for four levels, we can reach 160,000 people.  At that rate, our cause will only have to have 12% of people to actually contribute to make our first goal.  Help us by sharing.  It only takes a second!

story:
I first met "Steve" a little over a year ago through work I'm helping to support that's focused on implementing a long-term plan to end homelessness in Winnipeg.

(This isn't his real name, I don't feel I have the right to share his real name, that's up to him).

Three years ago he was pursuing a successful career in the marketing industry. Then, in a just a couple of months, a series of life's curve balls (including a devastating bout of depression) shook it all apart.

He found himself living in an abandoned car in a downtown Winnipeg lot. With no local family or supports, he lived in that car for 7 months, almost giving up before he was able to seek  and finally get the help he needed.

He built himself up, found stability and got back on his feet.

This is the back seat of the actual car he slept in for seven months. This was where he lived in Winnipeg.

Today he works part time running a support group for other formerly and currently homeless people in Winnipeg. He also volunteers tirelessly to share his story with schools, workplaces and other organizations to help people understand the crisis that his homelessness and advocate on behalf of those who cannot.

He supports himself and his partner, while also working hard to find full time work. His partner is also formerly homeless, and continues to suffer from debilitating mental health issues.

A series of unfortunate events has led to this week: the deadline for a deposit on a new apartment that they can't make in time. He needs $300. Or he loses the apartment and they face the prospect of being homeless again.

His message in desperation to a few people he knows over the weekend:

"Well if i don't get a miracle by tomorrow , [my partner] and i will be living homeless on the streets. When you constantly have to decide between food and shelter one will always lose. This is such a desperate situation. I know i can't survive out there this time around and [my partner] is in a state of shock, and the trauma is too much for her.. we need help"

The homelessness situation in Winnipeg is critical, and there is important work being done to address it. It's good work that has leadership around the community coming together to make a reality.

That doesn't change the reality today, where many people are facing terrible situations with little to no options.

But I know we can help Steve and his partner... today. If you can, please join me in helping him!

The money raised will go directly to paying their rental deposit so they can secure the apartment and not be left on the street. Any additional funds we are able to raise will go to providing a small "cushion" for rent, food and other necessities.
story_txt: I first met "Steve" a little over a year ago through work I'm helping to support that's focused on implementing a long-term plan to end homelessness in Winnipeg. (This isn't his real name, I don't feel I have the right to share his real name, that's up to him).Three years ago he was pursuing a successful career in the marketing industry.  Then, in a just a couple of months, a series of life's curve balls (including a devastating bout of depression) shook it all apart.He found himself living in an abandoned car in a downtown Winnipeg lot.  With no local family or supports, he lived in that car for 7 months, almost giving up before he was able to seek  and finally get the help he needed. He built himself up, found stability and got back on his feet. This is the back seat of the actual car he slept in for seven months. This was where he lived in Winnipeg.Today he works part time running a support group for other formerly and currently homeless people in Winnipeg.  He also volunteers tirelessly to share his story with schools, workplaces and other organizations to help people understand the crisis that his homelessness and advocate on behalf of those who cannot.He supports himself and his partner, while also working hard to find full time work. His partner is also formerly homeless, and continues to suffer from debilitating mental health issues.A series of unfortunate events has led to this week: the deadline for a deposit on a new apartment that they can't make in time. He needs $300. Or he loses the apartment and they face the prospect of being homeless again.His message in desperation to a few people he knows over the weekend:"Well if i don't get a miracle by tomorrow , [my partner] and i will be living homeless on the streets. When you constantly have to decide between food and shelter one will always lose. This is such a desperate situation. I know i can't survive out there this time around and [my partner] is in a state of shock, and the trauma is too much for her.. we need help"The homelessness situation in Winnipeg is critical, and there is important work being done to address it. It's good work that has leadership around the community coming together to make a reality.That doesn't change the reality today, where many people are facing terrible situations with little to no options.But I know we can help Steve and his partner... today. If you can, please join me in helping him!The money raised will go directly to paying their rental deposit so they can secure the apartment and not be left on the street. Any additional funds we are able to raise will go to providing a small "cushion" for rent, food and other necessities.

story:
In the fall of 2016 Wikileaks released the Podesta Emails that  contained pedophile code talk- terms such as 'pizza' , 'hot dogs', 'pasta' , 'map' and others used out of context and absolutely nonsensical considering the true meaning of these words- as it turns out these are known terms used by child pedophile/ child traffickers.

Podesta's code talk riddled emails led to many other individuals, particularly those inside the DC beltway including James Alefantis -owner of Comet Pizza in DC. After citizen investigators started to dig in and examine the 'JimmyComet' Instagram account many disturbing images as well as comments on those images were discovered.

In addition to that evidence a citizen journalist revealed just days ago that allegedly on or around December 5th, 2016 password protected pages on Comet Pizza's website were found to contain child pornography- apparently this evidence was submitted to the DC Police who asked the researcher to remain silent about the information presumably so they could conduct an investigation- FOIA requests since reveal no such investigation has occurred. 

​

Unfortunately this is not an issue exclusive to Washington DC or this particular scandal- it's far more expansive and global in nature. Our mission is simple- to end child trafficking and crimes against children and make our world safe for children again forever. We will achieve our goal as decent human beings united in an unrelenting campaign where EVERY DAY MATTERS- children are suffering and dying daily. 

​

Terms  Of Surrender (TOS)

​

1- Release ALL children to closest hospital

2- Surrender to authorities

3- Confess to your crimes

4- Beg for forgiveness

​

​

Thank you all for your ongoing support- we call upon all decent human beings- the time has come for us to stand shoulder to shoulder- by the millions- around the globe- and put and end to these crimes against children. It's time to come out from behind your web cams and key boards and take to the streets in peaceful demonstrations. The time has come for us all to talk to our friends, family, neighbors, and even strangers to spread awareness as most will feel compelled to act once they actually review the evidence at hand. 

​

Please consider organizing an event in your area- we will be happy to assist you in this endeavor. Grateful and love you all!

story:
Concerned Global Citizens: 

Fundraiser for Sawa


1.5 million Syrian refugees living in Lebanon

The ongoing wars and turbulence in the Middle East have caused a refugee crisis unparalleled in recent history.  This crisis has reached a critical tipping point, sending shock waves throughout the international community.  The challenge is staggering, but there are organizations in the fray making a difference at the local level by empowering individuals swept up in this struggle.  One inspiring group helping to make the world a better place is Sawa for Development and Aid, a non-for-profit group serving the refugee community living in Lebanon. 

How can we help?

In conjunction with a Concerned Global Citizens fundraiser event in NYC on October 21st, this campaign aims to support the efforts of "Sawa for Development and Aid".

We want to invite the participation of as many of our friends, family, and network as possible to raise awareness and material support.  We researched numerous organizations but wanted to work with an NGO directly engaged with the refugee community. Sawa came highly recommended through their efforts to empower women and children.

Our goal is to raise over $1,000 for Sawa so that they can continue their mission.


(Sawa and Heart Alliance International providing laughter yoga class for children)

Sawa for Development and Aid

Sawa provides education and social services for refugee women and children through their community centers and programs as follows:

Women's Empowerment Program

"Women receive social, psychological and professional assistance. Sewing/knitting workshops are provided, as well as soft grants for projects. SAWA organizes awareness sessions about sexual and reproductive health, gender based violence, soft skills, etc…"

Educational Program

"Provides a brighter future for over than 290 children, between the ages of 5 and 12. In terms of official schooling, we provide children with an education that is compliant with the Lebanese Official Curriculum. In the afternoon, children stay for a second shift, in which cultural and recreational activities (such as a musical education program, art classes, and athletic skills development) occur as part of a harmonic educational program in which mentors from the UK and from Lebanon are involved (musicians, famous artists, famous football coaches, etc. who mentor the teachers and animateurs who are recruited from the camps to put the program into action at the community center).

Join us on October 21st in NYC for a speaker/fundraising event!

Come mingle with concerned global citizens, learn more about the Syrian humanitarian crisis and how to support relief efforts.  

This evening will be the first of a tri-annual series of humanitarian events hosted by Concerned Global Citizens where we collectively explore ways to be of service.

Visit our Facebook Event Page here!

THANK YOU!

story:
It's Time WE Stop Police Brutality

The Ferguson tragedy, the deaths of Mike Brown, Tamir Rice and Eric Garner, the indictment of 18 Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies by the FBI for excessive force, the resignation of L.A. Sheriff LeRoy Baca in the wake of countless police brutality charges, the imprisonment of L.A. Sheriff's deputies for interfering with police brutality case witnesses...  There are far too many instances of rights deprivation, excessive force, police brutality and cover-up. We've chosen to take a stand, and, just as importantly, we've identified how to do it effectively. Please stand with us.

If not us, who?

The Problem (until now)

Police brutality is a wide-reaching issue in the United States and throughout the world with deep roots in economic and racial inequity, militarization of federal and local law enforcement agencies, the increasing use of law enforcement to collect revenue for bankrupt states and a bankrupt nation, and a house-of-cards economy that is showing signs of collapse--with the poorest among us the first to fall. No crowdfunding campaign can solve the entire issue. However, we've identified a specific problem where a little capital can effect significant impact on the greater issue.

The specific problem we seek to overcome with the Bad Cop No Donut campaign is the financial barrier to entry for victims bringing suit against police brutality offenders. Even if a lawyer takes a case on contingency basis and the victim/plaintiff is eligible for a low income waiver of court costs, there are still hard costs of suit that often cannot be paid. Expert witnesses and depositions primarily. Expert Witnesses cost $5-10,000, and court reporters for depositions are about $2,000 a day. So even if a victim of police brutality is willing to stand up, which is rare enough, the case dies if he or she doesn't have the $10-20,000 to cover the hard costs inherent in the discovery phase of any successful lawsuit. Thus the majority of offenders escape accountability... and they and their fellow officers continue to believe they can get away with excessive force... and the beatings go on... and the problem grows worse every day nationwide and throughout the "free" world.

The Solution

This campaign creates a not-for-profit private express trust and trust fund specifically to pay legal costs necessary to check the encroaching police state, demand accountability from public servants who use excessive force, and help stop the rampant police brutality problem. We start by financing one specific case currently in U.S. Federal Court, Ninth District: Alexander Vago v. County of Los Angeles et al, Case # 2:13-cv-00868-DMG-RZ. We believe this is a winnable case. How large the judgment or settlement will be, no one knows, but any judgment or settlement will include a recovery of costs of suit, which includes the funds raised here. When we recover the costs through settlement or judgment, we will then use the same money to fund other cases again and again. If we raise more here than required for the Vago case, which we hope to do with your generosity and assistance by spreading it through social media and the press, we will also fund other cases in parallel to the Vago case. And if this campaign is successful, we will use it as proof of concept and run a bigger campaign next in order to fund as many cases as we can and make a significant impact on this growing problem.

The Impact

Police brutality is on the increase for a number of reasons: 1) growing disregard for the unalienable rights of the people, especially minorities and people without money, 2) dehumanization that takes place based on economic status and/or race, 3) belief by many law enforcement officers that they can get away with excessive force, and 4) too many instances where the offenders do get away with brutal acts because it's too difficult and costly for the average man or woman to successfully punish them through the court system.

Bad Cop No Donut starts with successfully punishing offenders in order to regain a respect for our rights. In order to bring successful law suits to hold the offenders accountable, many victims need the type of financial resources we are creating with this private trust fund so they can successfully prosecute the offenders. If we, with your help, financially support the victims to prosecute the offenders, removing the financial hurdle that quashes most police brutality cases in favor of the offenders, we take away the ability of the offenders to get away with their offenses. As we successfully prosecute offenders, we also reduce the perception that offenders can get away with the use of excessive force. As this perception changes in the wake of increased threat of just retribution, the rights of the people will once again become primarily important to law enforcement officers, as they should be. If nothing else, officers will at least know they risk losing their career and livelihood if they don't respect your rights.

Where Your Dollars Go & What They Will Do

Financial details:

  • The first order of business is to win one important case. After that, we'll use the same money (plus additional funds raised), to fund more and more cases.
  • To win the first case identified for this effort, Alexander Vago v. County of Los Angeles et al, Federal Court Case # 2:13-cv-00868-DMG-RZ, we will need $13,000, as follows: $5,000 for a professional witness and $2,000 each for 4 court reporters to record the depositions of 4 witnesses. Every cent up to the $14,000 goal, after Indiegogo fees, will go directly to Mr. Vago to cover these costs.
  • Any amount raised above and beyond the goal of this campaign will be forwarded to a private trust fund to be managed as a private not-for-profit trust by the trustees of the Global Trust Education Network (GTEN.org, see our information below). Other court cases will be immediately considered for assistance, vetted and researched, and the funds will benefit other plaintiffs with strong police brutality cases.
  • If we fall short of the stated goal of at least $14,000, the Trustees of GTEN have pledged to assist in making up the shortfall to assure the success of this first important case win, so no donation will go to waste.
  • Every successful plaintiff, starting with Mr. Vago, will not only return the principal to the trust fund from recovery of court costs (to be used again and again) but will also pledge a portion of his or her awarded judgment or settlement to the trust fund to increase the trust fund value to help future victims. The trust fund will grow with every victory in court.
  • Your one-time contribution will fund an ever-increasing number of court cases, for an ever-increasing number of brave individuals to stand up for ALL of us and protect our unalienable rights in the face of the encroaching police state we are experiencing today.
  • If this crowdfunding campaign is successful, we will launch another campaign in the coming year to increase the capacity of the trust fund. We will seek, with your help and the help of others, to put a stop to police brutality across the United States of America and around the "free" world. We intend that the next campaign will also include fund raising for the re-education of law enforcement personnel regarding the unalienable rights of people. If anyone selects the $20,000 contribution perk on this present campaign, we'll already have a jump on this education initiative.

The Vago Case

The first case we've identified for this effort, Alexander Vago v. County of Los Angeles et al, Case # 2:13-cv-00868-DMG-RZ, is a Federal Court civil rights and excessive force case arising from egregious police brutality perpetrated by two Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies. We have fully vetted and researched this case and conclude on examination of the facts that it is a winnable case which presents an opportunity to set an example for law enforcement officers everywhere, hopefully just the first of many to come.

Selection of this first case was very different from the selection of future cases. This case was brought to our attention and gave us the idea to create this campaign and its resulting trust fund. We didn't know Mike Brown or Tamir Rice. We didn't know Alexander Vago either, but Mr. Vago came to us for help, and we decided to help. Then we chose to turn it into something bigger. The next victims we assist, once we have the funds to help and once we're a known source of assistance, will come from all over. The trust fund will financially enable anyone, regardless of economic status, to hold law enforcement officers accountable in court, helping to assure nobody can be profiled by police as a non-threat to their jobs and dehumanized because of economic status. And we see this as a path to economic justice and its direct and inextricably connected relative, racial justice. 

Alexander Vago was an hourly wage worker in a natural foods store, an ordinary guy, who is now unable to work and on disability since the incident described below. He was probably profiled as a low income nobody, and the Sheriff's deputies thought they could get away with dehumanizing and brutalizing Mr. Vago based on his economic status. 

Summary of the facts alleged in the case:

On May 15, 2011, Alexander Vago was brutally beaten by Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department Deputies Brent Bunch and Doug Duvall at a routine traffic stop for a minor traffic infraction. Mr. Vago was merely a passenger in the back seat of a car. He was unarmed and had no criminal record. There are multiple witnesses who will state under oath that he was calm and didn't pose any threat to the officers or anyone else. He never lifted a hand to fight back or even to defend himself. He didn't move. Nevertheless, the two deputies took turns tasing and stunning him in the head and neck about a dozen times until he keeled over in his seat half unconscious, then they maced his eyes at immediate range. Then they beat him with batons, meanwhile making jokes like, "Did you see him kick me?", as they proceeded to beat him in feigned retaliation for the mock acts they invented in their jokes. They beat him repeatedly in the head, the torso and the legs with batons. The attack was so severe that Mr. Vago was hospitalized, the injuries still persist today, and he is now physically and mentally unable to work and dependent on state disability coverage.

The photos below were taken of a few of Alex Vago's injuries three days after he was tased, stunned, maced, beaten and falsely imprisoned by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies and after having been treated at two hospitals for his injuries.

This civil rights action seeks compensatory and punitive damages for deprivation of rights and serious injuries received by Mr. Vago resulting from the May 15, 2011 roadside traffic stop. It is the Plaintiff's highest intention that the Defendants will compensate Mr. Vago and pay punitive damages and that the two offending deputies will never work again in law enforcement.

The full court complaint is available here: http://GTEN.org/forum/bad-cop-no-donut-forum. 

The entire case file is public in the Federal Court, Ninth District, Case No. 2:13-cv-00868-DMG-RZ. The parties are presently engaged in discovery proceedings. Mr. Vago will need $13,000 to complete discovery, as itemized above, or else the case will not proceed and these offenders will walk away without reprimand or accountability for their actions. Please help us ensure this will not happen this time.


The GTEN Trustees

The money raised from this campaign goes directly to Alexander Vago to fund his case. If we reach our goal in time, he will have what he needs to proceed with discovery and depose witnesses and the offending officers. All excess funds raised in this campaign, as well as costs of suit recovered after trial and additional funds pledged by Mr. Vago from the award of judgment or settlement, will be forwarded to a private trust fund managed by the Trustees of the Global Trust Education Network (GTEN).

GTEN is a private not-for-profit trust organization comprised of a network of individuals serving the common good through trusteeship of private and charitable trusts organized for educational, literary, scientific and spiritual purposes, to lessen the burden of governments, to defend and promote rights and freedom, and to actively assist in the sound, sustainable, enlightened evolution of mankind for a world that works for all life. 
For more information on who we are and what we're about, please visit our website http://GTEN.org or our YouTube channel GTEN Trustees at http://YouTube.com/GTENwebinars.

Risks & Challenges

Nothing is certain but death and taxes. Judges are like a box of chocolates; You never know what you're going to get. We're well aware that anything can happen in court. However, what's been happening to date is that only well-off individuals can afford to bring suit and cover the hard costs of discovery, so the cops routinely get away with police brutality. That needs to end, we see a way to significantly curtail it, and with your help we believe we can make a real impact.

The fact is... we need to win this first case. If we lose this first case, we may not have much of a trust fund for other cases. That said, we like our odds in the Vago case. We don't believe the offenders in this case can wiggle out of what they've done. Their lawyers have already tried repeatedly to get the case dismissed over the past two years, and they now realize it is not going away. We intend to hold the offenders and their employers fully accountable.

Other Ways You Can Help

This is an important issue and a timely campaign. Please help us spread the word through:

  • Social media
  • The Indiegogo share tools
  • Your email contacts
  • Your website
  • Your social groups
  • The press

The GTEN Trustees, Alex Vago, future victims of police brutality who will receive benefit from this trust fund, and the community at large thank you for your help in restoring liberty and justice for all by helping us hold law enforcement officers accountable for their actions.

FAQ

Is my contribution tax deductible? 

Maybe, though not necessarily. For a number of reasons we've chosen to establish a private not-for-profit trust and trust fund for this effort rather than create a public 501(c)(3) non-profit. So donations do not receive tax-deductible receipts in the way a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization could offer. However, expenses for books and education are tax deductible. Depending on the perk offered at your donation level, you may be able to deduct for education costs. To be sure, consult your tax preparer.

Why is this campaign establishing a not-for-profit private trust rather than a 501(c)(3) non-profit?

Given the nature of this undertaking, we feel it's best to keep this effort private in order to protect the privacy and safety of our donors, to curb political agendas, and to avoid political malfeasance. Since we are gearing up to "fight city hall", it's best that city hall doesn't control the organization, as would be the case with a US franchise entity such as a 501(c)(3) charity.

Will I be able to track the progress of the Vago case and future cases?

Yes! We've set up a section of the GTEN Forum at GTEN.org to update our contributors and the public on the ongoing status of the Vago case and the greater goals and achievements of this project beyond the Vago case. You'll find this at http://GTEN.org/forum/bad-cop-no-donut-forum.

What was the source of information for the dollar amounts needed to cover hard costs in the Vago case and future cases?

Mr. Vago filed his complaint pro se (without an attorney) and has now brought a lawyer on board to litigate the case on a contingency basis. His attorney informed him of the hard costs for a professional witness and court reporters. The GTEN Trustees verified these costs with our attorneys who have no part in the Vago case.

How do I submit a case for funding consideration?

If you would like us to consider your police brutality, excessive force or deprivation of rights case for funding assistance, please email us using the 'contact us' tab on the website header at http://GTEN.org.

What next?

Thanks for reading. Thanks for contributing. Thanks for helping us spread the word. Our truest intention is to raise not $14,000 for one case, but rather $100,000, $200,000, a million or three million. $14,000 brings two bad cops to trial. If we raise a million instead, we can assist about 70 victims at once. We're prepared to be in the not-for-profit business of assessing cases and assisting victims full-time to create meaningful change in police behavior, should such an opportunity arise by your will, your trust and your generosity.

If we fall short of the stated goal of at least $14,000, the Trustees of GTEN have pledged to assist in making up the shortfall to assure the success of this first important case win, so no donation will go to waste.
Every successful plaintiff, starting with Mr. Vago, will not only return the principal to the trust fund from recovery of court costs (to be used again and again) but will also pledge a portion of his or her awarded judgment or settlement to the trust fund to increase the trust fund value to help future victims. The trust fund will grow with every victory in court.
Your one-time contribution will fund an ever-increasing number of court cases, for an ever-increasing number of brave individuals to stand up for ALL of us and protect our unalienable rights in the face of the encroaching police state we are experiencing today.
If this crowdfunding campaign is successful, we will launch another campaign in the coming year to increase the capacity of the trust fund. We will seek, with your help and the help of others, to put a stop to police brutality across the United States of America and around the "free" world. We intend that the next campaign will also include fund raising for the re-education of law enforcement personnel regarding the unalienable rights of people. If anyone selects the $20,000 contribution perk on this present campaign, we'll already have a jump on this education initiative.    
The Vago Case


The first case we've identified for this effort, Alexander Vago v. County of Los Angeles et al, Case # 2:13-cv-00868-DMG-RZ, is a Federal Court civil rights and excessive force case arising from egregious police brutality perpetrated by two Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies. We have fully vetted and researched this case and conclude on examination of the facts that it is a winnable case which presents an opportunity to set an example for law enforcement officers everywhere, hopefully just the first of many to come.
Selection of this first case was very different from the selection of future cases. This case was brought to our attention and gave us the idea to create this campaign and its resulting trust fund. We didn't know Mike Brown or Tamir Rice. We didn't know Alexander Vago either, but Mr. Vago came to us for help, and we decided to help. Then we chose to turn it into something bigger. The next victims we assist, once we have the funds to help and once we're a known source of assistance, will come from all over. The trust fund will financially enable anyone, regardless of economic status, to hold law enforcement officers accountable in court, helping to assure nobody can be profiled by police as a non-threat to their jobs and dehumanized because of economic status. And we see this as a path to economic justice and its direct and inextricably connected relative, racial justice. 
Alexander Vago was an hourly wage worker in a natural foods store, an ordinary guy, who is now unable to work and on disability since the incident described below. He was probably profiled as a low income nobody, and the Sheriff's deputies thought they could get away with dehumanizing and brutalizing Mr. Vago based on his economic status. 


Summary of the facts alleged in the case:

On May 15, 2011, Alexander Vago was brutally beaten by Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department Deputies Brent Bunch and Doug Duvall at a routine traffic stop for a minor traffic infraction. Mr. Vago was merely a passenger in the back seat of a car. He was unarmed and had no criminal record. There are multiple witnesses who will state under oath that he was calm and didn't pose any threat to the officers or anyone else. He never lifted a hand to fight back or even to defend himself. He didn't move. Nevertheless, the two deputies took turns tasing and stunning him in the head and neck about a dozen times until he keeled over in his seat half unconscious, then they maced his eyes at immediate range. Then they beat him with batons, meanwhile making jokes like, "Did you see him kick me?", as they proceeded to beat him in feigned retaliation for the mock acts they invented in their jokes. They beat him repeatedly in the head, the torso and the legs with batons. The attack was so severe that Mr. Vago was hospitalized, the injuries still persist today, and he is now physically and mentally unable to work and dependent on state disability coverage.
The photos below were taken of a few of Alex Vago's injuries three days after he was tased, stunned, maced, beaten and falsely imprisoned by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies and after having been treated at two hospitals for his injuries.




This civil rights action seeks compensatory and punitive damages for deprivation of rights and serious injuries received by Mr. Vago resulting from the May 15, 2011 roadside traffic stop. It is the Plaintiff's highest intention that the Defendants will compensate Mr. Vago and pay punitive damages and that the two offending deputies will never work again in law enforcement.
The full court complaint is available here: http://GTEN.org/forum/bad-cop-no-donut-forum. 
The entire case file is public in the Federal Court, Ninth District, Case No. 2:13-cv-00868-DMG-RZ. The parties are presently engaged in discovery proceedings. Mr. Vago will need $13,000 to complete discovery, as itemized above, or else the case will not proceed and these offenders will walk away without reprimand or accountability for their actions. Please help us ensure this will not happen this time.



The GTEN Trustees
The money raised from this campaign goes directly to Alexander Vago to fund his case. If we reach our goal in time, he will have what he needs to proceed with discovery and depose witnesses and the offending officers. All excess funds raised in this campaign, as well as costs of suit recovered after trial and additional funds pledged by Mr. Vago from the award of judgment or settlement, will be forwarded to a private trust fund managed by the Trustees of the Global Trust Education Network (GTEN). GTEN is a private not-for-profit trust organization comprised of a network of individuals serving the common good through trusteeship of private and charitable trusts organized for educational, literary, scientific and spiritual purposes, to lessen the burden of governments, to defend and promote rights and freedom, and to actively assist in the sound, sustainable, enlightened evolution of mankind for a world that works for all life. 
For more information on who we are and what we're about, please visit our website http://GTEN.org or our YouTube channel GTEN Trustees at http://YouTube.com/GTENwebinars.
    Risks & Challenges 
Nothing is certain but death and taxes. Judges are like a box of chocolates; You never know what you're going to get. We're well aware that anything can happen in court. However, what's been happening to date is that only well-off individuals can afford to bring suit and cover the hard costs of discovery, so the cops routinely get away with police brutality. That needs to end, we see a way to significantly curtail it, and with your help we believe we can make a real impact.
The fact is... we need to win this first case. If we lose this first case, we may not have much of a trust fund for other cases. That said, we like our odds in the Vago case. We don't believe the offenders in this case can wiggle out of what they've done. Their lawyers have already tried repeatedly to get the case dismissed over the past two years, and they now realize it is not going away. We intend to hold the offenders and their employers fully accountable.

    Other Ways You Can Help This is an important issue and a timely campaign. Please help us spread the word through:  Social media The Indiegogo share tools
Your email contacts
Your website
Your social groups
The press   The GTEN Trustees, Alex Vago, future victims of police brutality who will receive benefit from this trust fund, and the community at large thank you for your help in restoring liberty and justice for all by helping us hold law enforcement officers accountable for their actions.FAQIs my contribution tax deductible? Maybe, though not necessarily. For a number of reasons we've chosen to establish a private not-for-profit trust and trust fund for this effort rather than create a public 501(c)(3) non-profit. So donations do not receive tax-deductible receipts in the way a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization could offer. However, expenses for books and education are tax deductible. Depending on the perk offered at your donation level, you may be able to deduct for education costs. To be sure, consult your tax preparer.Why is this campaign establishing a not-for-profit private trust rather than a 501(c)(3) non-profit?Given the nature of this undertaking, we feel it's best to keep this effort private in order to protect the privacy and safety of our donors, to curb political agendas, and to avoid political malfeasance. Since we are gearing up to "fight city hall", it's best that city hall doesn't control the organization, as would be the case with a US franchise entity such as a 501(c)(3) charity.Will I be able to track the progress of the Vago case and future cases?Yes! We've set up a section of the GTEN Forum at GTEN.org to update our contributors and the public on the ongoing status of the Vago case and the greater goals and achievements of this project beyond the Vago case. You'll find this at http://GTEN.org/forum/bad-cop-no-donut-forum.What was the source of information for the dollar amounts needed to cover hard costs in the Vago case and future cases?Mr. Vago filed his complaint pro se (without an attorney) and has now brought a lawyer on board to litigate the case on a contingency basis. His attorney informed him of the hard costs for a professional witness and court reporters. The GTEN Trustees verified these costs with our attorneys who have no part in the Vago case.How do I submit a case for funding consideration?If you would like us to consider your police brutality, excessive force or deprivation of rights case for funding assistance, please email us using the 'contact us' tab on the website header at http://GTEN.org.What next?Thanks for reading. Thanks for contributing. Thanks for helping us spread the word. Our truest intention is to raise not $14,000 for one case, but rather $100,000, $200,000, a million or three million. $14,000 brings two bad cops to trial. If we raise a million instead, we can assist about 70 victims at once. We're prepared to be in the not-for-profit business of assessing cases and assisting victims full-time to create meaningful change in police behavior, should such an opportunity arise by your will, your trust and your generosity.

story:
Summary

Driven by poverty to seek employment in Hong Kong, more than 320,000 (primarily women) domestic workers now toil in private residences hidden from public view and subjected to varying forms of abuse. Due to the hidden nature of this phenomenon, the extent of forced labour in Hong Kong (HK) is unknown. 

After volunteering for three years with a HK NGO providing legal advice to migrant domestic workers, I became convinced that many of the workers who were seeking assistance were in fact victims of human trafficking and specifically victims of forced labour.  

I am now determined to seek a PhD (Law) focused on Human Rights so that I am better prepared to continue helping this marginalized community. I am currently in my second year at the University of York, UK and I will return to Hong Kong this month for my field research.

Based on my experience, I saw first hand that many of the migrant domestic workers who leave their employers due to abusive working conditions are forced into conciliation with their employers when they make claims for their final wages and entitlements upon termination. This practice results in workers settling claims for much less than their contractual entitlement.  
While the circumstances of these cases are treated as a simple labour disputes, my view is that they are in fact cases of forced labour, a violation of human rights and a breach of Hong Kong's obligations to the Basic Law of Hong Kong and International Covenants.

I will spend six months working closely with local HK charitable and non-profit organizations as well as migrant workers determining and documenting the extent of forced labour within the  migrant domestic worker community.  At the same time, I will highlight that the conciliation process as applied is inconsistent with Hong Kong's obligations to  protect human rights, prevent abuses and punish violators. Additionally, the research will provide a solid foundation for advocating for changes in policy, practice and law. 

The International Labour Organization estimates that there are over 21 million victims of forced labour globally with over half being women and girls. Almost 19 million are exploited by private individuals, with domestic work being one of the most exploitative sectors.

Having had the opportunity to meet some of these women and understand first hand their struggles woke me to how unaware we are to injustice all around us and it has changed how I look at my life of privilege.  I am determined to take this topic out of the shadows by adding their plight to the ongoing dialogue on forced labor.

Poverty is one of the most challenging issues of our time. My project will not, and is not intended to cure poverty, but it might help a small group of Migrant Domestic Workers realize their dreams of caring for their families and being paid fairly for their hard work. 

Funding

I have self funded my education but this research phase will be costly as the cost of living in Hong Kong is very high. My goal is to raise $30,000 in funding supplement my personal expenditures towards travel, accommodation and living expenses for 6-8 months in Hong Kong. The bulk of expenses will cover accommodation which averages $2,000 per month ($12 -16,000) for a small serviced apartment.

The Impact

In 2011 I visited a woman in a small village in Indonesia. I had assisted her while she was a domestic worker in Hong Kong. She was underpaid (below the minimum legal wage) during her 4 years of employment and was owed approximately $120,000HKD ($15,484 USD). The resulting settlement from conciliation was $48,000 ($6,194 USD). Barely more than 1/3 of her entitlement and less than a family in the developed world spends in a month. When I visited her in Indonesia, I met her husband who is a truck driver on the road 6 days a week. I couldn't help but notice the large holes in the roof, the uninstalled window and door frames and the unused pile of sand outside. As we sat on the floor to share a meal, the woman explained the unused building material and apologized for the holes in the roof. She explained that the money she received from settlement was not enough to repair the house. She felt cheated and the four years spent working was all in vain. Her goals were not realized after all her hard work and sacrifice. 

This experience is not uncommon for many migrant workers globally and specifically in Hong Kong.  

unfortunately, I expect that I will meet many others like her during my stay in HK. Your contributions will help me make a small change for the better in their lives and potentially help change the process for many others. For contributors who want to stay in touch with progress, I would be commenting on my experiences in my Facebook page.

Risks & Challenges

The women who I will be meeting are often, frightened, destitute and traumatized. I must be cautious and ensure that by urging them to be part of my studies I am not contributing to their discomfort. As an impartial observer rather than  a volunteer as I was before, I must also avoid getting too involved in their plight.

I will manage this situation by working only with clients of recognized charitable or non-profit organizations that are prepared to give other support and advice as needed.

In instances where I meet someone who is in need of support such as short-term shelter or legal advice, the organizations I have selected as research partners are positioned to assist.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your support no matter how small would be greatly appreciated. Please contribute now by using the Indiegogo website or app.

If you cannot contribute to my cause at this time but would like to help domestic workers in Hong Kong fight for their rights, please tell your friends about Indiegogo and my work.

story:
"Na Ponta dos Pés" (On Tiptoe) is a social ballet project for girls from 4 to 15 years old, in Morro do Adeus, in the Complexo do Alemão, Rio de Janeiro's largest favelas complex.

 

The project was started without any support by Tuany Nascimento, a 23-year-old dancer, who was raised and trained on this neighborhood, and represented Brazil at international Artistic Gymnastics events during a flourishing career that was abruptly cut short by lack of resources.

In 2012, at age 17, she began teaching classes at Morro do Adeus, determined to give better opportunities to children in her community.

On these years more than 140 girls have already passed through the project, changing their lives in positive.

 

 

Brazil is going through a very complex time, involved in a great crisis at institutional, political, social and economic levels. This context has increased violence and drug trafficking in the favelas, with less police presence and battles between narco groups to take power. This is the case of Morro do Adeus, in which the Comando Vermelho (VC) is at war against the Third Commando Pure (TCP), making it one of the most dangerous and violent neighborhoods in Rio de Janeiro.

 

 

The place where the classes are currently taking place is a semi-open space that puts the girls at risk of a lost bullet. On multiple occasions it was necessary to cancel or interrupt a class because of shootings.

On these context we need the money to build a Community Center, a safe space for the project, away from the daily shootings, with all the essential things, like mirrors, shoes and ballet bar.

A new headquarters for "Na Ponta dos Pés", but also an open space to other social projects and the people of the community, with computers and library.

 

 

With a previous campaign of collective fundraising it was possible to build the foundations of the Community Center, which, because it was found on a hill, was necessary to do it with 2 meters of depth. 

The challenge is to raise at least $ 15,000 to complete the construction of the Community Center, the labor force will be executed by the residents themselves and relatives of the little girls. If more could be raised for the equipment would be great. 

Help us to provide a safe and dignified space for these little dancers to keep walking on tiptoe for life, and help a wonderful people like Tuany Nascimento, which are a true example to follow, to build a better world!!!

THANK YOU!!! :)

story:
Who Are We and What Are We Here For

Aloha!

 Jaquelynn Jeanne Collier and Raisa Klyne here! We’re just two girls who grew up as dear friends in Hawaii immersing themselves with every theatre opportunity our community had to offer. We both left for college in Canada and NYC, and gained generous opportunities that broadened our careers in Marketing and Theatre, respectively. In 2017, and coincidentally only months apart, we both moved back to the Big Island!

When we returned, we knew we needed to put our skills and craft into helping our community, and something we knew needed attention is the reproductive justice system within our community. Our island's population is at 186,738 and always growing. Since 2015, we have had ZERO free, reliable, and 100% confidential clinics. This does not sit well with us.

That being said, we have decided to put together a production of Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues this August in West Hawaii! We hope this production follows our mission to collaborate with our community by creating a work of theatre that will educate, inspire, and empower women and allies of any diversity. For this event, our additional mission is to raise $5,000 for Planned Parenthood Votes Northwest and Hawaii (PPVNH) & Planned Parenthood Greater Northwest and the Hawaiian Islands (PPGNHI) to increase the sexual education programs, free and safe consultations, and advocacy to fight for reproductive justice.

What We Need & What You Get

While our production of The Vagina Monologues is undergoing rehearsals for our one-night benefit performance on August 11th, 2018,  we want to go above and beyond for an organization that has done so much for so many women! We have been blessed enough to work with an incredible crew of female Big Island artists who have pledged thousands of dollars worth of merchandise to help raise additional funds for Planned Parenthood.

With every donation, you will receive a bundle of curated goods from artists and artisans from all over the Big Island! The Pledge Packs are as follows:

Pins & Stickers

$10 - The Vagina Warrior Pin Pack

$10 - The Cosmic and Wild Sticker Pack

$10 - The Nature Lover Sticker Pack

Art Prints

$15 - The Big Island Love Art Pack 

$25 - The Flower Power Art Pack

$30 The Women of Variety Art Pack

Skincare

$25 The Aloha Skincare Pack 

 

The Impact

Planned Parenthood has been providing safe and affordable reproductive health care for more than 100 years. Their dedication to women and families across the nation - and soon, across the world! - has been a pillar for women's right to access to reproductive healthcare for generations. While for many years, Planned Parenthood operated on the Big Island of Hawaii, lack of funding and a handful of other factors forced the two clinics on the island to close their doors in 2015. Since then, women of the Big Island have had little to no access to affordable reproductive healthcare. Our mission is to change that. 

Our team spoke with representatives of Planned Parenthood Votes Northwest and Hawaii  (PPVNH) as well as Planned Parenthood Greater Northwest and The Hawaiian Islands (PPGNH) to discuss the most efficient way to aid our local women. After a bit of research, we learned that PPGNHI has been working on this issue for some time. While the state of Hawaii will have a Planned Parenthood clinic open again this year, the clinic will only be open on the island of Oahu, leaving residents of the other seven islands with no access. This is where we can help! 

PPGNHI has put together a program through which patrons who are not on Oahu can receive the care they need with the help of vouchers. These vouchers include airfare and accommodations for those who are in need of health care but cannot afford to fly out to the clinic on Oahu. Our campaign's aim is to raise funds to help pay for these vouchers so that women of the Big Island who seek healthcare will have the opportunity to receive it without having to worry about having the funds.

Planned Parenthood's work doesn't stop there. In an effort to broaden their accessibility, Planned Parenthood has launched a mobile app that brings confidential and convenient STD testing and treatment to your doorstep. 

While Planned Parenthood has made great strides - made possible by the hard work of Planned Parenthood Votes - we are still in a tough fight. We understand that the real change needs to come from legislation and the only way to do that is to remain educated on current issues and vigilant in protecting Women's rights. That's where Planned Parenthood Votes Northwest and Hawaii comes in. The Big Island severely lacks access to reproductive health care and the fight to get our clinics back is a long battle. These funds will go towards the advocacy of reproductive justice.

The Risks

Not everyone is going to agree with us and we know that we won't win every time, but that's not going to stop us from trying!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people are not able to donate, but that doesn't mean you cant help! Heres' a list of other ways you can help Planned Parenthood!

  • Help us raise awareness by sharing this campaign on your social media platforms!
  • TALK to your Senators and Representatives!
  • Remain educated on the important issues and educate those you know! 
  • Keep fighting the good fight! 

Mahalo from the very bottom of these two small town girls' hearts for taking the time to get to know us and our mission.

While the state of Hawaii will have a Planned Parenthood clinic open again this year, the clinic will only be open on the island of Oahu, leaving residents of the other seven islands with no access. This is where we can help! 
PPGNHI has put together a program through which patrons who are not on Oahu can receive the care they need with the help of vouchers. These vouchers include airfare and accommodations for those who are in need of health care but cannot afford to fly out to the clinic on Oahu. Our campaign's aim is to raise funds to help pay for these vouchers so that women of the Big Island who seek healthcare will have the opportunity to receive it without having to worry about having the funds.
Planned Parenthood's work doesn't stop there. In an effort to broaden their accessibility, Planned Parenthood has launched a mobile app that brings confidential and convenient STD testing and treatment to your doorstep. 
While Planned Parenthood has made great strides - made possible by the hard work of Planned Parenthood Votes - we are still in a tough fight. We understand that the real change needs to come from legislation and the only way to do that is to remain educated on current issues and vigilant in protecting Women's rights. That's where Planned Parenthood Votes Northwest and Hawaii comes in. The Big Island severely lacks access to reproductive health care and the fight to get our clinics back is a long battle. These funds will go towards the advocacy of reproductive justice.
The Risks
Not everyone is going to agree with us and we know that we won't win every time, but that's not going to stop us from trying!
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people are not able to donate, but that doesn't mean you cant help! Heres' a list of other ways you can help Planned Parenthood!

Help us raise awareness by sharing this campaign on your social media platforms!
TALK to your Senators and Representatives!
Remain educated on the important issues and educate those you know! 
Keep fighting the good fight! 

Mahalo from the very bottom of these two small town girls' hearts for taking the time to get to know us and our mission.

story:
As a compassionate independent clinic, All Women’s Health has been serving patients throughout Tacoma and surrounding areas of the Pacific Northwest for over 19 years.  Through their time, they served the community by providing access to much needed healthcare services; allowing women to have control over their own bodies and destiny.  With the continuous attacks on reproductive rights  and the overwhelming cost of healthcare, AWH found themselves unable to sustain, and made the difficult decision to close their doors approaching their 20th anniversary; jeopardizing reproductive access to women in need.  Through a collaborated effort, dedication, and a passion for reproductive freedom, Rise With Change, pllc was created; carrying forward AWH's mission.

As leaders within the reproductive community, we pride ourselves on empowerment through healthcare, are dedicated to our patients, and are deeply committed to providing the best standard of safe, quality care.  We embrace diversity and provide culturally relevant and individualized services; ensuring that all people are treated with respect, compassion and dignity.  We are the United State of Women and stand alongside our patients to make the best decisions for themselves and their futures.

story:
We’re Celebrating the Influence of Virginia’s Women

 

Women have played an undeniable role in the founding and shaping of the Commonwealth of Virginia and the United States.

Virginia wants to call attention to the importance of women in a tangible way by becoming the first state to build a women-only monument which will be located on the Capitol grounds.

Twelve of the state’s boldest and most innovative females will be put on a pedestal (literally) and made into individual statues.

We are partnering with the Women's Legacy Project to help fund the monuments and bring this project to life. Help us create a physical reminder of the power of the past to inspire future generations to continue to enable women to succeed!

 

How Can I Help?

Don't just read about history, be part of shaping it!

We are helping to raise as much of the $3 million needed as possible and our first goal is $30,000.

There are 2 specific ways you can help support this campaign.

1) Donate to help us commemorate these 12 iconic women while honoring a woman in your life too! Just in time for Mother’s Day!

2) Share with your friends! Whether on social media or in real life this campaign is major and is setting a new precedent for females and we need your word-of-mouth support.

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Check out our perk levels for all the details and options!


This Sounds Great, But Who Are You?

We’re the 2019 Commemoration / American Evolution! Our mission is to highlight the significance and modern relevance of several important events that occurred in Virginia in 1619. One of these is the role of women. These events strongly influenced the development of the colony and shaped the foundation of the United States.


Starting now through 2019 we’ll be having multiple digital and live events throughout the state and country. Check our website for all the details - americanevolution2019.com.

story:
Hello, my name is Zakkiyyah Nazeeh and I have some exciting news to share with you. I am going to be the recipient of the 2017 Women of Distinction award for my work with women, young women, and girls.

This award is very special to me, to be recognized and honored for the wonderful work I have done over the last 25 years. My career goals have been to provide support through counseling with women who are incarcerated, homeless, addicted to substances, physically, emotionally and sexual abused.

Many of the women and young women believe their current situation is hopeless and they have no alternatives to live a productive life. I have been able to help them look at their lives through a different colored lens. The lens shows them they are strong, worthy, intelligent and resourceful women. I share my motto with them:

You are #1, treat yourself as such...

I am a member of Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated and I am the Northern California State Director. In this position, I have had the opportunity to provide services to women, young women and girls in our communities who need support, and most of all I have the opportunity to be a mentor to some of the young women in Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated.

Celebrating Women International is a non-profit organization founded in 2013. The organization aims to mobilize women across the globe to honor, recognize and celebrate the contribution of women for their leadership capabilities to assist other women to thrive in the world so they can lead productive lives.

Oh, I almost forgot the award ceremony will be held December 2, 2017, in Nassau the Bahama. Within the next 45 days, I need your support to raise funds in order that my granddaughter and I may travel and receive the 2017  Women of Distinction Award.

 

With Your Contributions, I Can

Purchase a Round Trip Airline Ticket two from California to Nassau, Bahamas

Submit the required Hotel Deposit 

Purchase formal attire for myself and my granddaughter

Transportation 

Misc Traveling Fees

 

The Impact

In my earlier message, I shared one of the reasons why receiving the Woman of Distinction award is so important to me.  I would now like to share another reason this award is important to me.

I am the first woman in my family who graduated from college and received both an undergraduate and graduate degree. My granddaughter Marshawna is the 4th generation of women in my family who has completed her undergraduate degree in Physiology.

My granddaughter and I have always had a very strong relationship, and she has been my companion from birth. I recall one of my most exciting moments was when she attended the ceremony to receive my Master’s Degree.  Marshawna was 2 years old, holding my hand tightly as she and I walked across the stage to receive my Master’s Degree. That was a proud day for me and to have my granddaughter by my side witnessing the moment was the cherry on top.

 As we left the stage and returned to our seat, Marshawna asked, "what did you win"? I shared with her; I did not win anything but rather received an award for my studies in school. Well, at 2 years she did not really understand what I was saying, but she smiled and went to sleep. She continued to attend many meetings, social events, and ceremonies with me.

Marshawna plans to attend nursing school and become a Nurse Practitioner. Her focus is to assist young pregnant women who may not have access to adequate health care to ensure a healthy and thriving child. I am blessed to see my legacy continues, as Marshawna is also a member of the Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated.  I am passing her the torch so she can continue the work of supporting women and girls.

With your generous contribution, Marshawna will again be able to hold my hand tightly as we walk across the stage to receive the 2017 Women of Distinction Award in Nassau, the Bahamas on December 2nd. 

 

Thanking you in advance,

 

Zakkiyyah Nazeeh

story:
Short Summary

Elizabeth M. Fink fought for human rights for disenfranchised people of all walks of life, most prominently as a member of the Attica Brothers Legal Defense team. In her 23 year struggle for recognition for the people killed, injured, and tortured at Attica prison she was continually presented with challenges from state authorities regarding incriminating evidence. The evidence was routinely moved, hidden, or destroyed, while authorities claimed it had been lost.

Despite their efforts she discovered a trove of material, including:

1. A complete video recording of the assault made by a guard in the prison.

2. Photographs of the yard immediately after the assault that include clear depictions of torture. 

3. Autopsy photos proving that every man who died at Attica, including the hostages, was killed by bullets fired by the New York State Police.

4. Complete recordings of important video documents, including the McKay Commission Report, the documentary film Ghosts of Attica, television appearances by Fink and former inmate Frank "Big Black" Smith, as well as Fink's final on-camera interview before her death.

Some of the photographs from the archive were recently provided free of charge to historian Heather Ann Thompson for her book Blood in the Water. Thompson worked with Fink while researching the book and describes a similar experience dealing with the State of New York.

Prior to her death in September 2015, Fink began overseeing the processing of her archive for digital distribution to all interested parties. She wanted to make the collection freely available to the public in perpetuity, so no one could claim it had been 'lost' ever again.

The Fink estate is now tasked with seeing this project to completion, a goal we intend to reach in 2017.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds will go to purchase specialty equipment needed for digitizing slides, a less expensive option than obtaining outside services. We also need preservation items like protective sleeves for the photographs, post-production services for processing hours of VHS tapes, and hard drives for distribution of the material for website construction, researchers, and journalists. Money will be used to establish a permanent online portal for access to the complete archive, including commentary on the material from members of the Attica Brothers Legal Defense team, and testimonials from surviving Attica Brothers.

Documentary filmmaker and archivist Michael Hull was a personal friend of Fink's who she trusted to handle the digitization, organization and distribution of her archive. He was working on the archive with Fink until her death and has continued with the blessing of the estate, as well as her colleagues, friends and family. He has been working without pay, leading the project with his wife Morgan Foley, a longtime television news producer who was also a friend of Liz and frequent walker of her dog Sadie.

The goal of the project is to make the material freely available to anyone who wants it, so there are no perks to hand out. We will include your name in a list of Made Possible By donors that will live with the archive, but any money we receive will go directly to preserving and spreading the word about this vital record of American history.

If we don't reach our entire goal, funds will go to preserving the archive first and distributing it second, with the hopes that other interested parties will be able to publicize its importance and availability. Funds pledged above the goal amount will go to the production of an uncompromising documentary film based on Fink's final interview and her archive.

The Impact

This project is important because it remains the benchmark event for the use of state power against American civilians in the last hundred years. The version of events as reported by Richard Nixon and Nelson Rockefeller is in sharp contrast to the version told by medical examiners, National Guardsmen, prisoners, and others in the immediate aftermath. Anyone who deviated from the narrative told by the state was punished personally and professionally, but the evidence uncovered by Fink makes it clear they were being truthful.

In the conversation happening about policing in America today, we see echoes of the tactics used by powerful people in the past. There is a playbook of sorts that includes bullying, obfuscation, and repeating false narratives, all leading to hyperbolic threats of chaos and open war in the streets. Racial stereotypes and class divisions are key elements. Whether at Attica in 1971 or Ferguson in 2014, the study of these events can help us recognize them before they get out of hand, and hopefully reach more reasonable conclusions.

Making this evidence available to all Americans will help future generations hold their representatives to task, a vital duty in any democracy, and will help further vindicate those who are still living with this enormous event.

Risks & Challenges

The risk we are facing is that the State of New York continues to deny that their employees engaged in systematic torture of inmates, despite the evidence present in this collection.

The primary challenge is in organizing the material and making it accessible to people with all levels of knowledge about the event. We intend to create guided tours of the material augmented with commentaries by people who experienced both the chaos in 1971, and the legal pathways that led from it. We feel this is the best way to introduce the subject matter to anyone who isn't familiar with the Attica uprising and how it resonates in today's fractured political world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Send books, magazines, letters, etc., to inmates (here are some useful tips) http://www.prisonpro.com/content/sending-books-...

Share our page with people who you think would be interested

Talk about the humanity of incarcerated people

Teach people about the conditions in American prisons. Television isn't doing it justice.

story:
Short Summary

I am Yael Calhoun, the Executive Director of GreenTREE Yoga, a well-established 501c3 charity nonprofit. Our mission is to bring the healing benefits of yoga to underserved populations and to those who serve them, which we’ve been doing successfully for over 10 years. Our focus is on using the body-based modality of yoga (simple stretching and mindful breathing) to heal trauma and vicarious trauma. Visit www.greentreeyoga.org to see all the programs and training materials we have developed to help people heal trauma.

Yvette Melby, LCSW, RYT, and I developed this "Train the Trainer" Program to meet the needs of staff and refugees at various national and international organizations.  We are in the second year.

What We Need & What You Get

This $5,000 campaign is to build on $25,000 in funding (plus $20,000 in in-kind donations) already received to fund a project already in progress.  We will use all funds we to match funding for three projects:

  1. $2,500.00: To donate 5 ‘Train the Trainer” kits to international and national refugee agencies, like IRC (International Rescue Committee) and Catholic Charities.  A 10-minute introduction to the kit is available upon request (greentreeyoga@comcast.net)

“The IRC health and psychosocial camp staff said the manuals made it easier to teach yoga … The Karenni Women's Organization representatives expressed great interest to use these manuals in their safe houses or domestic violence shelters in the refugee camps in Thailand as well as in villages in Burma/Myanmar.”  ~Thai/Burma Refugee Camp:  University of Utah Bridging Borders Program as reported by Trinh Mai, LCSW, University of Utah School of Social Work

2. $750.00: To translate the flip charts into Arabic.  We already have funding to translate into Spanish, Somali, and Swahili. 

3. $1,250: To provide stipends to refugee women community leaders to participate in the “train the trainer” programs to share the healing benefits of yoga with their groups from.

What you Get

$20 Shanti the Monkey Coloring Book

$30  2 Shanti the Monkey Posters

$50  Yoga for Caregivers DVD/CD

$100  Picture Book “Yoga Makes Me Feel …”

$300 Signed Shanti the Monkey Print (Svea Lunoe, Alaska artist)

$500  Signed Shanti the Monkey Print, Picture Book, and Yoga for Caregivers DVD

The Impact

We have completed the first year pilot project. 

With additional funding, we want to increase the # of people benefitting three-fold.

2016 Pilot Program:

  • 50 flip charts distributed to sites in Utah, Partners in Health clinic in Mexico, and an IRC* program in Thai/Burma refugee camp.
  • Directly benefited about 200 staff and refugees.

 “… Sensitive to traumatized individuals. I love the gentle approach and emphasis on reducing traumatic responses…!”

“ All the material was very clear and easy to understand.  It was great!”

“Trauma-sensitive material and preparation was great – thinking about language and choice.

“Our staff found the materials informative, easy to use, and extremely helpful both for self-care and to use with client in individual and group settings. We work with severely traumatized individuals and staff self-care is key.” ~ Brent Pace, LCSW, Clinical Director, Utah Health and Human Rights (UHHR)  (UHHR is a direct service and advocacy agency that promotes the health, dignity, and self-sufficiency of refugees, immigrants, asylum seekers, and asylees who have endured severe human rights abuses, including torture and severe war-related trauma. )

 “GreenTREE Yoga is an organization that is making a positive difference in the lives of individuals in our community, And with funds to develop the “Train the Trainer” program they will be able to do so much more. The program is comprehensive and sustainable… and incorporates cultural considerations to ensure successful implementation,”  ~ Rosemarie Hunter, Ph.D. LCSW Direction University Neighborhood Partners, U of Utah

 

Risks & Challenges

We have completed a successful pilot project. We have received funds to continue to expand the program in 2017.  We have agencies interested in partnering with us. As we raise more money, we can provide more services to these very stressed agencies. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute funds, please considering using the Indigogo Share Tool to let others know about our efforts to provide support to both refugees and those who provide key programs.

Thank you so very much for whatever support you can provide to us.

Please enjoy FREE yoga breaks at our website: greentreeyoga.org FREE link.  Breaks for home, office, schools, and special needs children!
