story:
What is FICHA UCHI? 

In the Swahili Language native to Kenya, the phrase Ficha Uchi means to hide nakedness.  Our organization has adopted this name and has changed the expression of the meaning to signify a “Restoration of Dignity”.  Our goals are simple: We want to make sure that every primary school aged child has a respectable school uniform, one that is not torn, dirty or causes psychological harm to a growing mind. The early results of our implemented plan has been profoundly impactful to the families of 728 students clothed by Ficha Uchi Campaign.

For many elementary school aged children growing up in Mathare, going to school is an immense financial burden on their families. Only those fortunate enough to pay school fees are formally educated and often have to travel great distances just to attend school daily.  This often pushes the adults in Mathare to work multiple low paying jobs to give their children the chance for a better life.  A struggle and story familiar to every family thoughout the world.  We send our children to school so that they have an opportunity to be better then us. 

In Kenya, most parents are not able to buy new school uniforms for their children each academic year.  As an alternative, parents are forced to buy used school uniforms that are often barely adequate.  These children start every day of school at a disadvantage not only because of the neighborhood they come from, but also the condition of the clothing in which they attend school.  Many children are bullied and made to feel inferior by their peers, sowing the seeds of lifelong self-esteem and self-worth issues. 

We have had great early success with the Ficha Uchi Campaign.  To date, we have internally funded the uniforms worn by 728 students in 6 schools in and around the slum of Mathare on the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya.  We have learned much about the process of partnering with primary schools and parents who are overwhelmingly in support of our efforts.  We offer the schools, parents and indirectly, the community, an opportunity to participate in this part charity, part self-help movement to overcome this common social problem with a simple scalable model.

If you believe the old adages “be the change you want to see in the world” and “a rising tides lift all boats” take this opportunity to join our campaign.  

Ficha Uchi is a continuation of a movement to self empowers the poor of Mathare to better their lives by giving them hope through education.

What is the purpose of the School Uniform?

There are many theories about the value of a school uniform.  Some argue that uniforms bring the students a range of benefits: from a sense of belonging or fitting into a certain school thus bolstering the level of pride students have in schooling, to the belief that the uniform improves the learning ability of students by reducing distractions and sharpening focus on schoolwork by making the classroom a more serious environment.

Perhaps most importantly, a uniform means students don't have to worry about peer pressure when it comes to their clothes. When everyone is dressed the same, worrying about what you look like isn't so important. There is no competition about being dressed in the latest trend, which would put a great deal of financial pressure on students and parents. Potential bullies have one less target for their insults: it is hard to make fun of what someone is wearing when you're dressed exactly the same.

What has Ficha Uchi done so far?

The Ficha Uchi Organization was launched in March 2015, and we have had amazing results.  We have partnered with 6 primary schools to date and have clothed 728 children.   Our efforts have been supported by our fellow Kenyan community of people who care and our work has been fueled by our love of our community.  Here is a snap shot of our accomplishments:

Our School Partnership Total Number of Pupils Number of Students FICHA UCHI Clothed  Total Cost to Restore Dignity (USD)
Genesis Joy   Primary School 900 100 1500
Huruma Primary School 1300 118 1770
Ofafa Jericho Primary School 915 130 1950
Nairobi River Primary School 1500 120 1800
Makuyu Primary School 780 120 1800
New Pumwani Primary School 1400 140 2100


So what does my contribution do for the kids of Mathare? 

Good question.  Every donation helps not only children in need of a dignified school uniform, but also helps the community of Mathare in three different ways. Here how it works: 

Event Day

The management team visits schools to quantify the needs of the students for school uniforms, usually 10-15% of the school's enrollment. We then engage well-wishers and sponsors with actual quantity and details of the uniforms targeted to the needy pupils. Through social media, we mobilize for fabrics, other accessories (threads, buttons, canvas, and cotton) and then engage local tailors as a means of empowering local communities. On the day of visit, we organize motivational talks and finally, link beneficiary pupils to career coaches.

Ficha Uchi Job Training

In collaboration with the Billian Music Family Centre (Mathare, Kenya) the Ficha Uchi team organizes job training sessions for able bodied adults looking for employment as a tailor.  We train adults, who are often the parents of a recipient of a Ficha Uchi supplied school uniform, in advanced tailoring skill-set.  In exchange for their efforts, we employ them at a discount labor rate for future tailoring needs of a school. The economic empowerment from not only paying adults to participate, but giving them a skill-set, has had great benefits to our adult community as many have secured external employment as a result.  

Ficha Uchi "Buy Back" Program (Sustainability Initiative)

Our uniforms typically have a lifespan of two years . As a measure of sustainability, our "Buy Back" policy allows our past beneficiaries to return, gently used school uniforms that a child has out grown.  Ficha Uchi will pay one dollar ($1) for every gently used school uniform, and the child can re-enroll in our program for another school uniform.  The second hand uniforms will then form part of second batch of donation to the respective schools. Under this policy, we seek to make our uniforms open to the more able families at a subsidized fee. In addition to freely providing uniforms to between 100-200 needy pupils per school, we will give an opportunity to those who are more able to purchase uniforms at a dramatically reduced fee.  This policy will also provide an incentive for families to take good care of the donated uniforms, thus curbing unnecessary waste. Through Ficha Uchi's "Buy Back" policy, we seek to cut operational cost, further engage our communities involvement in our movement and ensure our sustainable model as we scale to size.

Who are we?

Ficha Uchi Initiative is the brain child of five university students from Mathare slums of Nairobi, Kenya in collaboration with the Chantal Paydar Foundation (San Diego, USA). The members include:

1.  Billian O. Ojiwa (Co-Founder, Chairman)

“I believe in the power of education in shaping economies. I am part of this campaign because I know the knowledge I have can help change Africa. I stand to be a pillar of change through this initiative.”

2.  Kevin O. Nyafwa (Co-Founder, Chief Executive Officer)

“I am part of Ficha Uchi Initiative because I believe in a future built through a sense of self-worth and dignity. With education as my tool, I want to inspire a generation through this initiative.”

3.  John S. Muraguri (Co-Founder, Head of Corporate Relations)

“My love for children drove me into joining hands with this team of great minds to be a pillar of change to a generation. I would like to see these children get quality education irrespective of their environment.”

4.  Douglas Aganyo (Co-Founder, Head of Public Relations)

“My personal experience having to endure the embarrassment of going to schools in tatters made me join hands with these like minded team in seeing no kid goes to school in tatters.I believe there is always a bright future within today’s pain and I want to help these kids see this.”

5.  Aaditi Rajput (Co-Founder, International Relations Coordinator)

“My experience studying in the U.K. made me realize how less a person’s potential is determined by where she was born. I just want to help a kid out there know that he/she is the best there is and even if tatters today, he can be a world leader tomorrow. I joined Ficha Uchi Initiative as a candle of Hope to help lighten life of a less privileged African child.”

6.  Remo Moomiaie-Qajar, M.D. (Partnering Organization)

"Through the work we have done at the Chantal Paydar Foundation and our native partnerships in communities like Mathare, we see many needs.  One that is often overlooked but profoundly important in the development of children towards getting an education that opens doors to adult hood opportunities is not only the access to education, but the quality of the experience of schooling.  It's hard to change a national school system, but it's easy to make sure kids have the minimums they need to fit into that system, and gain from its benefits.  Clothing is often overlooked because we have no concern for it in the US, but imagine if your child showed up in torn clothes, and the relentless bullying they would be subject to.  This happens every day, and is a nightmare that doesn't relent in Mathare.  This is a kind of problem that is fixable from the comfort of your home office, this is a problem that we can all solve together." 

Why be Inspired?

Our Initiative is inspired by our personal experience growing up as poor children in Mathare and remembering the small and large challenges we had to navigate to make a better life for ourselves and our families.  All our paths had one thing in common: Education, Education, Education.  Although we are old enough to laugh at our successes and failures, we can all appreciate the simple things in life that would have made life so much more easier for us growing up.  

A home to 500,000 people squeezed into 3 square miles, the Mathare slum is the second largest slum in Kenya. Nothing is simple in Mathare, but a sense of self-worth and dignity can be.  With a single item of clothing, the school uniform, a  child from any socio-economic background can be on the same level as their peers.  Freeing children of the social pressure of being a target for bullying optimizes that child's natural capability to learn and grow.  It's a simple act to help us achieve deep and long lasting consequences.  

We sincerely hope you act and be a part of our movement to Restore Dignity, FICHA UCHI.

Our
uniforms typically have a lifespan of two years . As a measure of sustainability, our
"Buy Back" policy allows our past beneficiaries to return, gently used school uniforms that a child has out grown.  Ficha Uchi will pay one dollar ($1) for every gently used school uniform, and the child can re-enroll in our program for another school uniform.  The second hand uniforms will
then form part of second batch of donation to the respective schools. Under
this policy, we seek to make our uniforms open to the more able families
at a subsidized fee. In addition to freely
providing uniforms to between 100-200 needy pupils per school, we will give an opportunity to those who are more able to purchase uniforms at a dramatically reduced fee.  This policy will also provide an incentive
for families to take good care of the donated uniforms, thus curbing unnecessary
waste. Through Ficha Uchi's "Buy Back" policy, we seek to cut operational cost, further engage our communities involvement in our movement and ensure our
sustainable model as we scale to size.


Who
are we?
Ficha Uchi Initiative is the brain child of five
university students from Mathare slums of Nairobi, Kenya in collaboration with
the Chantal Paydar Foundation (San Diego, USA). The members include:
1. 
Billian
O. Ojiwa (Co-Founder, Chairman)
“I believe in the power of education in shaping
economies. I am part of this campaign because I know the knowledge I have can
help change Africa. I stand to be a pillar of change through this initiative.”
2. 
Kevin
O. Nyafwa (Co-Founder, Chief Executive Officer)
“I am part of Ficha Uchi Initiative because I believe
in a future built through a sense of self-worth and dignity. With education as
my tool, I want to inspire a generation through this initiative.”
3. 
John
S. Muraguri (Co-Founder, Head of Corporate Relations)
“My love for children drove me into joining hands
with this team of great minds to be a pillar of change to a generation. I would
like to see these children get quality education irrespective of their
environment.”
4. 
Douglas
Aganyo (Co-Founder, Head of Public Relations)
“My personal experience having to endure the
embarrassment of going to schools in tatters made me join hands with these
like minded team in seeing no kid goes to school in tatters.I believe there is
always a bright future within today’s pain and I want to help these kids see
this.”
5. 
Aaditi
Rajput (Co-Founder, International Relations Coordinator)
“My experience studying in the U.K. made me realize how less
a person’s potential is determined by where she was born. I just want to help a
kid out there know that he/she is the best there is and even if tatters today,
he can be a world leader tomorrow. I joined Ficha Uchi Initiative as a candle of
Hope to help lighten life of a less privileged African child.”
6.  Remo Moomiaie-Qajar, M.D. (Partnering Organization)
"Through the work we have done at the Chantal Paydar Foundation and our native partnerships in communities like Mathare, we see many needs.  One that is often overlooked but profoundly important in the development of children towards getting an education that opens doors to adult hood opportunities is not only the access to education, but the quality of the experience of schooling.  It's hard to change a national school system, but it's easy to make sure kids have the minimums they need to fit into that system, and gain from its benefits.  Clothing is often overlooked because we have no concern for it in the US, but imagine if your child showed up in torn clothes, and the relentless bullying they would be subject to.  This happens every day, and is a nightmare that doesn't relent in Mathare.  This is a kind of problem that is fixable from the comfort of your home office, this is a problem that we can all solve together." 


Why
be Inspired?
Our Initiative is
inspired by our personal experience growing up as poor children in Mathare and
remembering the small and large challenges we had to navigate to make a better
life for ourselves and our families.  All
our paths had one thing in common: Education, Education, Education.  Although
we are old enough to laugh at our successes and failures, we can
all appreciate the simple things in life that would have made life so much more
easier for us growing up.  
A home to 500,000 people squeezed into 3 square miles, the Mathare slum is the second largest slum in Kenya. Nothing is simple in Mathare, but a sense of self-worth and dignity can be.  With a single item of clothing, the school uniform, a  child from any socio-economic background can be on the same level as their peers.  Freeing children of the social pressure of being a target for bullying optimizes that child's natural capability to learn and grow.  It's a simple act to help us achieve deep and long lasting consequences.  
We sincerely hope you act and be a part of our movement to Restore Dignity, FICHA UCHI.

story:
Hello My Precious Contributors,

First of all, let me introduce myself, my name is Ahmed Al Kilani , I am the Palestinian ambassador against children and women violence in Gaza, Palestine for 6 years. I raised many campaigns to help poor families from my own money and with my friends help. I have a team of volunteers who seek for helping and improving the lives of poor people in Gaza. You can check up my YouTube Channel by my name, where there are many videos about my previous campaigns. 

Second, I will explain the reasons to raise this urgent campaign. Through my previous campaigns, I noticed that the Palestinian occupation by Israel impacts children’s everyday lives. Palestinian authorities are greatly dependent on international aid, financial resources are limited and public services are not up to standard. Moreover, reports from non-governmental organizations show that Israel has used force to suppress pro-Palestinian demonstrations, using tear gas and shooting into the crowd without hesitation, even where there are children. The Israel army has defined a stone as a dangerous projectile in the same category as a real bullet. So if a child throws a stone at an Israeli soldier, the latter can respond in force and the child can be sentenced to up to 20 years in prison.

Poverty
Israeli restrictions on the free movement of people and goods are major obstacles for the Palestinian economy.

In 2012, the unemployment rate was 27% and according to recent statistics, 26% of Palestinians live below the poverty line.

In Gaza – the most impoverished area – one in two adolescents has the chance to work.

The effects of poverty on children’s lives are numerous: their schooling often remains incomplete because they leave school at a very early age, usually to work and provide for the needs of their families. Early marriages of young girls and adolescent crime are both consequences of poverty.

Right to Education

In Palestine, approximately 70% of children go to primary school.

Access to education is difficult for children who live in refugee camps and villages that do not have a school.

According to a 2013 UNICEF study, more than 2,500 children within educated communities travel through at least one checkpoint per day to go to school – a situation that contributes to school dropouts and child labor.

Furthermore, the number of classes offered is insufficient, which leads to overcrowding, teaching is of the poorest quality and the schools lack resources and materials.

In Gaza, following Operation Cast Lead in 2012, many schools were damaged or destroyed. In 2013, more than 123,000 children had to discontinue their schooling according to UNICEF.

Right to Health Care

In Palestine, the infant mortality rate is seven times higher than that of Israel. Indeed, 30% of Palestinian children die before the age of five. The causes of this high infant mortality rate are varied: anemia, nutritional deficiencies or even severe malnutrition.

Access to health care services can prove extremely problematic in Palestine due to the presence of the wall and checkpoints. Testimonies have been recorded of cases where families found themselves blocked by the Israeli army when they wanted to go to a hospital for treatment of their sick children. Sometimes, if medical treatment is delayed, the outcome can be fatal. During the conflict, many hospitals or clinics were also destroyed, depriving children of their right to health.

Right to water
With water resources being very limited, hygiene is often marginalized in favor of satisfying vital necessities (eating and drinking). Otherwise, the consumption of non-potable water also leads to severe sicknesses in children (diarrhea, hepatitis, etc.).

In Gaza, 95% of the water is unsuitable for human consumption. It is so polluted that it is estimated the territory will have no more drinkable water by 2016, an effect that will be irreversible by 2020. The high level of nitrate (notably due to poor management of wastewater) is the source of many sicknesses that affect babies and children.

 Right to have warm winter

Everyone in the world loves winter to play inside the hose with heater and warm weather. However many poor families in Gaza hate winter because their houses will be full of water and cold weather and without heater, they just fire the woods to get warm. Their houses damaged through the previous wars that caused leak and water enters their houses from everywhere. Also, they don’t have heavy clothes to keep them warm from that bad weather and the damaged leaky house.

 

Child Marriages

Even though the legal age of maturity is fixed at 18 years old, child marriages are still commonly practiced in Palestine since one in ten girls are married between 15 and 19 years of age, with 2% of those marriages occurring before the girl is 15.

These marriages can have negative effects on young girls who do not know what the consequences are. In fact, more often than not, after getting married the girls must become wives by looking after the housework and their husband. Additionally, following these marriages the girls frequently become pregnant and have to then take care of their offspring, even though they are still children themselves.

 

In conclusion, my aim is get rid of every trouble faces those needy children and poor families. So please help me to draw a smile and bright their mind with useful information may help them and help the whole world one day who knows. 

Your generosity gives children a smile

Support our Campaign!

Accept my respect and appreciation

 

Kind Regards,

Ahmed Al Kilani

story:
Anette Pekrul, former hostage in Iraq
When I was 29, a dream came true for me when I finally, after ten years trial, managed to get a job on a big construction site inMiddle East. I have been working on Basra International Airport in Iraq and I was employed by one of the biggest and best reputed construction companies in Germany. It was a huge challenge as we were only 5 women in a team of 500 men. Very fast I was respected by my colleagues and found first Iraqi friends. We invited each other and learnt about our cultures. During the weekends I discovered the beautiful country and visited historical places – like Babylon or the Hanging Gardens of Semiramis. I stood at the places where Euphrates and Tigris meet, where once was the paradise. The work went well and our Airport was in operation. On 7th August 1990, I wanted to be home in Germany to celebrate my 30th birthday. My dream was over on 2nd of August, when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. The first time in my life I was involved in war. The situation escalated and I was kept hostage for ten weeks. Instead of having a birthday party I wrote my will. Our situation became worse from week to week – no food, no water and no sign that we could ever leave the country alive. Day by day we were working on our plans how to escape, but our chances were close to zero. At that time I learnt about true Arabic friendship. Even the poorest under the poor helped me. They gave me food and would have hidden me in case of emergency. What the Iraqis did for me, I will never forget. The boss of our company managed to rescue us and just some weeks later the Gulf War started. Back in Germany, I watched the War in TV. I was thinking of my Iraqi friends and praying for them. I could not sleep at night. I had nightmares. I almost drove crazy. Six months after the war I heard in the news that more than five hundred thousand children under five years have died lack of food and medicine. That was my call to action. I started to collect and buy food and medicine, arranged all documents, even an official allowance from UN and started transportation to Iraq. From Jordan to Baghdad by truck 1800 kilometers through desert ... Since then, I am engaged in helping people in need. But this time I am able to help in my home country. The experience of war and being kept hostage changed my life, my values and my targets.


We can! They can!
Of course, I started to help immediately when the first refugees arrived here in the small city of Staßfurt/Eastern Germany. We shared clothes and food and tried to give a warm welcome. That was last year! Meanwhile, the media is full of the refugee crisis. Our city, too. More than 60 million people are leaving their countries. Germany and some European countries are overstrained in handling the arriving people. We had the first minus degrees two days ago. Winter is coming and we lack a housing crisis. In Germany, it is getting somehow discomfort. The politicians don’t show up with solutions. The demonstrations are increasing dramatically. Last week 200.000 people have been protesting in Magdeburg – 100.000 pro and 100.000 contra the asylum politics. Civic society is getting nervous and afraid. Could you imagine that their could be a simple solution which can help immediately and counteract the problem? Being daily involved as a volunteering social assistant in helping refugees, I was asking myself for several months – how might we change this difficult situation? And I will never forget the day, again a family was brought from a camp and being in a hurry to fill-out the documents, the ballpoint pen cracked into two pieces. Meanwhile, we were already communicating via mobiles and Google Translate in about 30 languages, but for bureaucracy we still need tons of paper and ballpoint pens! The refugees mostly standing next, not knowing what is going on, not knowing what will happen with them. Why don’t we just use digital technology and make the refugees active partners in the process? They all own a mobile and a good one, because they need to find their way and want to survive the escape from their home countries. Why don’t we just give them the App – they can choose their language, be informed about the new systems, have basic information about their new home country. They could even start to learn the language in advance or while waiting for days in refugee camps. If you further imagine that the app will connect all appropriate stakeholders plus volunteers – even every single small local Government will profit as we are finally going to have digital technology in all city halls. So what do you think, shall we try to finance more ballpoint pens or shall we change refugees from petitioners to designers of the Future? Let us make the change and help to keep the social freedom in Europe.
Kurzbeschreibung


Hallo, mein Name ist Anette Pekrul. Nach vielen Jahren im Business bin ich seit einigen Jahre eine Sozial-Unternehmerin, eine Kämpferin für nachhaltige Veränderungen zugunsten unseres Planeten und Beitragende zur Entstehung einer resilienten Gesellschaft.
In Staßfurt/Sachsen-Anhalt habe ich ein Bürgernetzwerk (Staßfurt initiativ) gegründet, das Bürgerinnen und Bürger zur Mitgestaltung ihrer und unserer Zukunft einlädt und aktiviert. Als vor einem Jahr die ersten Flüchtlinge aus Syrien nach Staßfurt kamen, wurden wir sofort aktiv. Wir haben gesammelt, Deutschkurse, Kinderprogramme und mehr eingerichtet und sind Ansprechpartner, Unterstützer und Begleiter bei der Integration geworden. Die Anzahl der Ankommenden hat sich drastisch gesteigert - eine Infrastruktur für die Ankommenden gab es nicht. Seit Juni gibt es ein Konzept im Salzlandkreis, das auch Soziallotsen als erste Ansprechpartner für die Ankommenden bestellt. Es gibt drei in der Stadt Staßfurt, ich bin eine von ihnen. Wir arbeiten viel, intensiv und eng zusammen. Parallel zu unserem Engagement haben wir all die Stationen, Hürden und Herausforderungen auf dem Weg zur Integration dokumentiert und die Struktur für ein IP-basiertes Integrationsmanagement konzipiert. Das Konzept ist fertig - alle Mitwirkenden in dem Willkommensprozess wurden eingebunden, auch die Geflüchteten.
Eine fertige Software wäre für alle am Integrationsprozess Beteiligten in Sachsen-Anhalt, Deutschland und anderen europäischen Ländern absolut hilfreich. 

Im Endspurt zum praxisfähigen Einsatz unserer Software bitten wir um finanzielle Unterstützung, um unsere Software möglichst schnell einsetzen zu können (bevor ein Chaos ausbricht). Unsere Integrationsmanagement-Software wird  für alle Beteiligten eine Win-Win Situation schaffen. 

(PS: Alle Beteiligten sind interessiert; die jeweilige Projektantragsdauer für Fördermittel ist jedoch zu lang. Wir denken, wir brauchen unsere Lösung JETZT!)

 "Yes, we can: REFUGEES WELCOME"
Im Moment steht es eher infrage, ob wir dem Zustrom Geflüchteter gewachsen sind - selbst Akteure in der täglichen Migrationsarbeit erhalten immer mehr Hilferufe von Kolleginnen und Kollegen, sogar aus Nachbarländern. Immer mehr Engpässe, Überlastungen und knapper werdende Ressourcen werden öffentlich bekannt. Erste Anlaufstellen für überforderte Ehrenamtliche werden eingerichtet ...

Wir sind davon überzeugt, wir können das schaffen - und unsere Software könnte der Schlüssel zu schneller Hilfe sein. Yes, we can!

 Die „Integration-App“ ist zur praktischen Anwendung für alle Akteure im Asylanten-Ankommens- und Betreuungsprozess entwickelt worden. Es handelt sich um ein digitales Netzwerk, das schnelle Kommunikation und Information aller Beteiligten, auch der Geflüchteten, ermöglicht. Die Plattform ist multilingual und sehr einfach in der Anwendung. Die Anwendung beginnt bei der Ankunft der Geflüchteten in Deutschland, unterstützt die Verteilung auf die Landkreise und steuert ab der Meldung der Ankunft bei den Kommunen den Ankommensprozess. Soziallotsen werden in den Kommunen informiert und „übernehmen“ die Ankommenden. Durch die Soziallotsen werden die Ankommenden dann mit Unterstützung der Integrationsmanagement-App in der Landessprache begrüßt und detaillierte Daten werden erfasst, der Zugang zum Online-Deutschkurs freigeschaltet, etc. ... Da die Soziallotsen bei behördlichen Gängen begleiten, haben Sie die beste Information über den Sachstand im Asylverfahren. Die Daten werden im Intranet aktualisiert und stehen somit zum Beispiel dem Jobcenter, der Schule oder Kita zur Verfügung. Der Asylbewerber weiß durch das Intranet, was er als nächsten Schritt erledigen muss und kann viele Informationen über die Deutsche Kultur, Werte und unser System einfach in seiner Landessprache nachlesen und aktiv mitwirken. Außerdem enthält das Intranet Kontaktdaten und ermöglicht auch die direkte Kommunikation – so zum Beispiel zu Menschen aus dem gleichen Herkunftsland oder Sprachraum.

Für Führungspersönlichkeiten wie zum Beispiel Innenminister, Landräte oder Bürgermeister wird auf Tastendruck eine Gesamtübersicht der Situation in ihrem Verantwortungsbereich möglich.

Unser Ziel/Wirkung

• Wir können es schaffen, aus der aktuellen Zuwanderungs-Überforderung einen schnellen, effizienten und strukturierten Ankommens- und Migrationsprozess zu gestalten, Tausenden, wenn nicht Millionen von Menschen helfen und so einen Beitrag zum Erhalt unseres sozialen Friedens leisten.
• Vernetzung und Kooperation von öffentlichen Einrichtungen (Kommunen, Institutionen, Behörden), sozial- und privatwirtschaftlichen Unternehmen, Soziallotsen, Geflüchteten und ehrenamtlichen Bürgerinnen und Bürgern
• IP-basiertes Integrationsmanagement inklusive Hilfe zur Selbsthilfe für Geflüchtete und Ehrenamtliche

Wieviel Geld wir brauchen und wofür

Wir benötigen 63.000,- Euro, die wie folgt eingesetzt werden:
• Honorar-Kosten für externe Mitarbeiter und Mitgestalter der App für 3 Programmierer, 1 Designer, 30 Übersetzer, 2 Assistenten - 75 Prozent (47.250,- Euro)
• 9-Sitzer Bus (gebraucht) für Behörden-Fahrten und Transport von Spenden wie zum Beispiel Möbeln, Kleidung, Spielzeug - 10 Prozent (7.500,- Euro)
• Anschaffungs- und Organisationskosten für zahlreiche Kleinigkeiten, die uns den Freiraum für die Programmierung der Software geben. Zum Beispiel Fahrten zu Behörden, Kauf von dringend Notwendigem bei der Ankunft von Flüchtlingen (mal fehlen Lebensmittel, weil selbst die Tafel keine mehr hat; Schmerzmittel werden benötigt oder es fehlt ein Kinderwagen, dann wieder etwas anderes) - 5 Prozent (3.150,- Euro) 

Sollten wir das Funding-Ziel nicht erreichen, würden wir die Spenden natürlich auch für unsere Flüchtlingshilfe einsetzen und auch veröffentlichen, was wir damit finanzieren. An unserer Software arbeiten wir dann natürlich dennoch weiter.

Webseite zu unserer Crowdfunding Kampagne:
http://www.integration-app.weebly.com

Als vor einem Jahr die ersten Flüchtlinge aus Syrien nach Staßfurt kamen, wurden wir sofort aktiv. Wir haben gesammelt, Deutschkurse, Kinderprogramme und mehr eingerichtet und sind Ansprechpartner, Unterstützer und Begleiter bei der Integration geworden. Die Anzahl der Ankommenden hat sich drastisch gesteigert - eine Infrastruktur für die Ankommenden gab es nicht. Seit Juni gibt es ein Konzept im Salzlandkreis, das auch Soziallotsen als erste Ansprechpartner für die Ankommenden bestellt. Es gibt drei in der Stadt Staßfurt, ich bin eine von ihnen. Wir arbeiten viel, intensiv und eng zusammen. Parallel zu unserem Engagement haben wir all die Stationen, Hürden und Herausforderungen auf dem Weg zur Integration dokumentiert und die Struktur für ein IP-basiertes Integrationsmanagement konzipiert. Das Konzept ist fertig - alle Mitwirkenden in dem Willkommensprozess wurden eingebunden, auch die Geflüchteten. Eine fertige Software wäre für alle am Integrationsprozess Beteiligten in Sachsen-Anhalt, Deutschland und anderen europäischen Ländern absolut hilfreich. 
Im Endspurt zum praxisfähigen Einsatz unserer Software bitten wir um finanzielle Unterstützung, um unsere Software möglichst schnell einsetzen zu können (bevor ein Chaos ausbricht). Unsere Integrationsmanagement-Software wird  für alle Beteiligten eine Win-Win Situation schaffen. 
(PS: Alle Beteiligten sind interessiert; die jeweilige Projektantragsdauer für Fördermittel ist jedoch zu lang. Wir denken, wir brauchen unsere Lösung JETZT!)
 "Yes, we can: REFUGEES WELCOME"Im Moment steht es eher infrage, ob wir dem Zustrom Geflüchteter gewachsen sind - selbst Akteure in der täglichen Migrationsarbeit erhalten immer mehr Hilferufe von Kolleginnen und Kollegen, sogar aus Nachbarländern. Immer mehr Engpässe, Überlastungen und knapper werdende Ressourcen werden öffentlich bekannt. Erste Anlaufstellen für überforderte Ehrenamtliche werden eingerichtet ...
Wir sind davon überzeugt, wir können das schaffen - und unsere Software könnte der Schlüssel zu schneller Hilfe sein. Yes, we can!
 Die „Integration-App“ ist zur praktischen Anwendung für alle Akteure im Asylanten-Ankommens- und Betreuungsprozess entwickelt worden. Es handelt sich um ein digitales Netzwerk, das schnelle Kommunikation und Information aller Beteiligten, auch der Geflüchteten, ermöglicht. Die Plattform ist multilingual und sehr einfach in der Anwendung. Die Anwendung beginnt bei der Ankunft der Geflüchteten in Deutschland, unterstützt die Verteilung auf die Landkreise und steuert ab der Meldung der Ankunft bei den Kommunen den Ankommensprozess. Soziallotsen werden in den Kommunen informiert und „übernehmen“ die Ankommenden. Durch die Soziallotsen werden die Ankommenden dann mit Unterstützung der Integrationsmanagement-App in der Landessprache begrüßt und detaillierte Daten werden erfasst, der Zugang zum Online-Deutschkurs freigeschaltet, etc. ... Da die Soziallotsen bei behördlichen Gängen begleiten, haben Sie die beste Information über den Sachstand im Asylverfahren. Die Daten werden im Intranet aktualisiert und stehen somit zum Beispiel dem Jobcenter, der Schule oder Kita zur Verfügung. Der Asylbewerber weiß durch das Intranet, was er als nächsten Schritt erledigen muss und kann viele Informationen über die Deutsche Kultur, Werte und unser System einfach in seiner Landessprache nachlesen und aktiv mitwirken. Außerdem enthält das Intranet Kontaktdaten und ermöglicht auch die direkte Kommunikation – so zum Beispiel zu Menschen aus dem gleichen Herkunftsland oder Sprachraum.
Für Führungspersönlichkeiten wie zum Beispiel Innenminister, Landräte oder Bürgermeister wird auf Tastendruck eine Gesamtübersicht der Situation in ihrem Verantwortungsbereich möglich.

Unser Ziel/Wirkung
• Wir können es schaffen, aus der aktuellen Zuwanderungs-Überforderung einen schnellen, effizienten und strukturierten Ankommens- und Migrationsprozess zu gestalten, Tausenden, wenn nicht Millionen von Menschen helfen und so einen Beitrag zum Erhalt unseres sozialen Friedens leisten.• Vernetzung und Kooperation von öffentlichen Einrichtungen (Kommunen, Institutionen, Behörden), sozial- und privatwirtschaftlichen Unternehmen, Soziallotsen, Geflüchteten und ehrenamtlichen Bürgerinnen und Bürgern• IP-basiertes Integrationsmanagement inklusive Hilfe zur Selbsthilfe für Geflüchtete und Ehrenamtliche
Wieviel Geld wir brauchen und wofür
Wir benötigen 63.000,- Euro, die wie folgt eingesetzt werden:• Honorar-Kosten für externe Mitarbeiter und Mitgestalter der App für 3 Programmierer, 1 Designer, 30 Übersetzer, 2 Assistenten - 75 Prozent (47.250,- Euro)• 9-Sitzer Bus (gebraucht) für Behörden-Fahrten und Transport von Spenden wie zum Beispiel Möbeln, Kleidung, Spielzeug - 10 Prozent (7.500,- Euro)• Anschaffungs- und Organisationskosten für zahlreiche Kleinigkeiten, die uns den Freiraum für die Programmierung der Software geben. Zum Beispiel Fahrten zu Behörden, Kauf von dringend Notwendigem bei der Ankunft von Flüchtlingen (mal fehlen Lebensmittel, weil selbst die Tafel keine mehr hat; Schmerzmittel werden benötigt oder es fehlt ein Kinderwagen, dann wieder etwas anderes) - 5 Prozent (3.150,- Euro) Sollten wir das Funding-Ziel nicht erreichen, würden wir die Spenden natürlich auch für unsere Flüchtlingshilfe einsetzen und auch veröffentlichen, was wir damit finanzieren. An unserer Software arbeiten wir dann natürlich dennoch weiter.
Webseite zu unserer Crowdfunding Kampagne:http://www.integration-app.weebly.com

story: We are a group of progressive women looking to make a difference in a post 2016 election world. We need to raise money to continue to grow our cause on the heels of an incredibly successful peaceful rally in New Jersey (1/21/17). This money will go towards growing our website and continuing to reach out to people who feel alone and don't know where to go to volunteer, donate and offer their help in other ways.

story:
In Good Faith 

Talking about race in the United States is difficult and necessary. White people feel attacked as they confront privilege, guilt and anger. Black people are tired of explaining why their lives matter. The result feels like a mine field, so that even would-be allies withdraw into the safety of their own racial group.

In good faith, a black woman and a white man started talking as we watched the United States convulse with racial upheaval and during a contentious presidential election and its divisive aftermath.

Through our idiosyncratic process of listening, hearing and recognizing productive difference, we were cracked open by new and sometimes difficult insights about ourselves and who we choose to call “other.”

We created this project to show how its possible to leave our respective silos and at least shout across the prairie. 

What We Need & What You Get

These conversations need a home, other than on our respective laptops. We are creating a website, e-book and limited-edition podcast. Here's a sneak preview of our website --  www.messyconversationsingoodfaith.com 

We need to raise $5,000 to make that happen.

Your donation pays for all costs associated with a professional website development and design, production costs of the e-book and podcast, and related shipping costs for this crowdfunding campaign. Any additional money raised will be donated to a specific nonprofit organization that works to improve race relations in the United States. 

We are extremely grateful for and excited about the people who have already stepped up to donate free services. But we need your help to make this project happen.

Why We Can't Wait 

We cannot afford to remain in respective silos of silence, bigotry and ignorance. Political and social forces threaten to further divide us, so that it becomes harder for like-minded people to resist oppression and tyranny. 

We aren't saying that by having a conversation with someone who doesn't look like you or have the same background will impeach Trump, eliminate racism, and make the world a better place. But we are saying that we each have to try. This is what this project attempts to do, why we need your help and ask you to join the conversation. 

We Are Not Experts 

We really can't say this enough. In fact, it's plastered on nearly every page of the website. 

Kerra Bolton is a political communications consultant, writer and artist. A.J. Hartley is the Russell Robinson Professor of Shakespeare Studies at the University of North Carolina in Charlotte and best-selling novelist. Nothing in those descriptions say "qualified to talk about race." 

But real race conversations, the ones that happen outside the glare of television lights, happen between ordinary people who are trying to make sense of themselves and each other. That's one of the many reasons why these conversations are messy. 

In the messiness is also a story about a friendship that grows as people grapple with race -- one of the most divisive, difficult and personal subjects. We fight...a lot. We also laugh a lot. We want to show people that it's possible to have difficult conversations and remain friends. We need your help to make this happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes folks want to help, but don't have the money. If this is you, don't worry. Here are other ways you can help and join the conversation:

  • Share our campaign on your social media. Tweet. Facebook. Instagram. 
  • Use the hashtag #ingoodfaith
  • Share the link to our website -- www.messyconversationsingoodfaith.com 
  • Sign up on our website for updates and resources

Thank you for your support. Join the conversation!

story:
About Lucia

Hello. I am a mother, entrepreneur, and distance runner. I am also the granddaughter of immigrants. This September I will attempt to set the self-supported Fastest Known Time (FKT) on the Oregon Coast Trail. The trail stretches from the Columbia River some 400 miles south to the California border. There will be low points—times when pain or fear or exhaustion make the whole idea seem stupid. And that is when I will remember that this expedition is a privilege, a choice. That is not the case for thousands of immigrant families who endure long, dangerous, exhausting journeys to reach the United States. These families have made unimaginable sacrifices in pursuit of the American Dream. There is nothing more American than that.

Now more than ever, immigrant families need legal and community support to stay safe and together. That's why I am using this run to raise money for the Immigration Counseling and Advocacy Program (ICAP) run by Lutheran Community Services in Yamhill County, Oregon.

This spring I attended ICAP's Fiesta en la Plaza and heard firsthand from immigrant families who are safe and together thanks to the work of ICAP. It was clear that ICAP is more than services. The staff and volunteers—many immigrants and refugees themselves—play a crucial role in helping new families feel welcome and valued in the community.

The Impact

Your gift of support restores hope and helps our immigrant friends and neighbors:

  • Reunite with their families
  • Protect their children against deportation
  • Realize the dream of becoming US Citizens
  • Find sanctuary through crime victim visas
  • Experience the advantage of consistent case management

What Your Donation Will Do:

Every gift helps us support the immigrant community of Yamhill County:

  • $50  for an immigrant's citizenship classes. 
  • $100 pays for outreach events, empowering immigrants to know and access their rights.
  • $250 Provides DACA Assistance to a young adult brought to U.S. as a child to gain legal status.
  • $500 Assists a crime victim in obtaining a non-immigrant Visa.
  • $1,000 Allows us to support a family of three to reunite with their loved ones in the US.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to give financially, you can still support this campaign:

    • Contact LCSNW about volunteer opportunities
    • Share this campaign on instagram and facebook.
    • Send this information to friends or family who might be able to support

    Thank you all for your support!

story:
Let me tell you the story: I knew I was gay since the day I was born. The first thing that came out of my mother's womb was a rainbow flag. My parents were also very happy when I made my first rainbow poo. Later on, when I was growing up, the first word I said was "gay" and the second "lgbt". When I turned 6 my parents sent me to a public primary school.  I quickly found a circle of faithful "fag hags" and went with them to my first pride at the age of 10. I came out to my family at the age of 12. They were a bit shocked but suspected that. Since then they were cheering me up to find my prince charming, even giving a lift at night to a local gay club. It took me some time but after numerous dates and shorter or longer relationships I found my perfect match at the age of 18. We married two years later with our families and friends attending the wedding. We went on the honey moon trip to San Francisco and lived our rainbow lives happily ever after.

Does it sound familiar? Probably not for most of us. This is how it should be but gay life is not always colorful. In some countries we fight for rights to marry but in others gay people cannot even live their lives openly. I come from Poland which is a fairly conservative country so I know how important is support. That's why I decided to launch this campaign.

WHAT ARE THE GOALS OF THE CAMPAIGN?

The main goal of the campaign is to raise funds that will allow me to open online store with handmade items, many of them in gay design. All items are made by me and my mom from high quality fabrics. Money from sales would be spent among the others on:

- 10% of the total monthly income from sales once per month would be sent to a gay organization to support a project chosen in the voting by customers. It includes donations from this campaign. If I exceed my goal of 1000 euros I will increase the number to 20%. 

- expansion and promotion of my Facebook page Happy Gay. I run this page successfully since 2014 with over 3500 followers. Page is devoted to gay rights but I post only positive news from lgbt world therefore gay people can find safe space far from every day drama. In the future I'm planning to open a website connected to the Facebook page as well.

https://www.facebook.com/happyngay

By supporting this campaign you can not only get beautiful handmade products for reasonable price but also support gay rights and the dream to have my own business and become gay activist as well.

WHAT YOUR MONEY WILL BE SPENT ON?

- purchasing new fabrics

- with my mom we are probably unable to catch up with higher demand therefore I will need to hire additional people to help with production

- creating and maintaining a website

- buying a new camera to take photos of items

If I don't manage to collect enough money, raised funds will be spent on covering production expenses, partly on boosting Happy Gay page and 10% donation. No matter how much money I raise, you will get your item anyway ;)

WHAT CAN YOU PURCHASE?

- (rainbow) Coffee/Tea Set. The set includes cup warmer and pad (no cup included). You can choose rainbow or another pictured design. Warmer can be also used as necklace. Cotton 55%, acrylic 45%. Washable at 30 degrees.

 

- Pride Bracelet or Heart-Shaped Key Ring. Acrylic. Washable at 30 degrees.

- Phone Case. You can choose rainbow desing or a more traditional one. All options pictured below are available. If you wish you can add flip and button to the rainbow one as well. All cases fully cover the phone. Cotton 55%, acrylic 45%. Washable at 30 degrees.

- Rainbow Scarf. Length roughly 150 cm, acrylic, very soft, antipilling, crochet, washable at 40 degrees.

The campaign lasts three weeks (21 days). At the end of the campaign money will be transferred from Indiegogo platform to me. It means all items will be sent at the turn of February and March. Expected time of delivery to Europe is March, out of Europe March or the beginning of April depending on the post.

After ordering an item, send me a message with your choice (if applicable).

PAYMENT BY PAYPAL AVAILABLE FROM ALL COUNTRIES. YOU JUST NEED TO CHOOSE EURO AS CURRENCY. Bank transfers are possible as well.

Have you still any questions? Don't hesitate to ask!

story:
Resumen/Summary

La Convención de las Naciones Unidas sobre los Derechos del Niño (CDN), reconoce a la familia "como grupo fundamental de la sociedad y medio natural para el crecimiento y el bienestar de todos sus miembros, y en particular de los niños", y afirma que el niño, para el pleno y armonioso desarrollo de su personalidad, debe crecer en el seno de la familia, en un ambiente de felicidad, amor y comprensión. Adicionalmente establece que se deben realizar todos los esfuerzos necesarios para lograr que los niños permanezcan con su familia, se reintegren a ella, o en su defecto, se debe encontrar otra solución apropiada y permanente.

Sin embargo, por diferentes variables como la pobreza, migración, hacinamiento, violencia intrafamiliar, consumo de alcohol y drogas, o la situación de salud de padres y madres, el riesgo de desintegración familiar se incrementa, vulnerando de esta manera los derechos de los niños y niñas.

The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, recognizes the family “as main group of the society and natural environment for the growth and welfare of its members, and specifically, children”, and says that in order to get the full and harmonious development of their personality, they have to grow within a family, in a cheerful, loving and understanding environment. It also establishes that all the needed efforts should be done to make children stay with their families, reintegrate to them, otherwise a proper and permanent solution should be found.

However, due to different reasons such as poverty, migration, overcrowding, family violence, alcohol and drugs consumption or fathers and mothers’ health, the risk of family disintegration increases, violating this way children’s rights.

Esta situación en Bolivia es alarmante y se refleja en las siguientes estadísticas:

  • 6 de cada 10 niños y niñas viven en situación de pobreza.
  • 3 de cada 10 niños y niñas sufren desnutrición crónica antes de los 5 años.
  • 8 de cada 10 niños y niñas sufren violencia (física, psicológica y sexual)
  • Más de 165.000 familias están en riesgo de separarse.

This situation in Bolivia is alarming and is expressed in the following numbers:

  • 6 out of 10 children live in poverty.
  • 3 out of 10 children suffer chronic malnutrition before turning 5 years old.
  • 8 out of 10 children suffer violence (physic, psychologic and sexual)
  • More than 165.000 families are at risk of separating.

Es por esta razón que Aldeas Infantes SOS trabaja en Bolivia más de 48 años en la prevención del abandono y la restitución del derecho a una familia de niños y niñas que perdieron el cuidado de sus padres.

That is why, SOS Children’s Villages works in Bolivia for more than 48 years, preventing the child abandonment and trying to restitute the right to a family for children who lost the care of their parents.

“Irremplazables” es una campaña de recaudación de fondos para atender a 3 familias en alto riesgo social, con el fin de asegurar su desarrollo integral y evitar de esta manera su desintegración

“Irreplaceable” is a fundraising campaign to help three families at high social risk, with the objective of assuring their integral development and avoiding this way their separation.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes/What we need and what you get

Necesitamos recaudar $15.000, los cuales cubrirán los costos directos de apoyo a estas 3 familias en las siguientes áreas:

  • Desarrollo integral de los niños y niñas: salud, educación, nutrición y desarrollo psicosocial.
  • Desarrollo de los padres, madres o cualquier otra persona que ocupe ese rol: autoestima, salud, pautas positivas de crianza, estimulación temprana, oficio laboral, y liderazgo.

Para todas las personas que nos ayuden, existirán recompensas ¡pensadas desde el corazón!, desde mensajes de agradecimiento hasta videos personalizados agradeciendo el compromiso con la causa, y también obras de arte exclusivas de un reconocido artista boliviano (Amigo de Aldeas Infantiles SOS) con su respectivo certificado de autenticidad.

We need to raise $15.000, which will cover the direct expenses of support to these three families in the following areas:

  • Integral development of children: health, education, nutrition and psychosocial development.
  • Development of fathers, mothers or any other person who is taking this role: self-esteem, positive childrearing guidelines, early stimulation, job and leadership.

For all the people who contribute, there will be rewards thought from the heart!, from thank-you messages to personalised videos thanking for the commitment to the cause and also exclusive works of art from a renowned Bolivian artist (a friend of SOS Children’s Villages) with its certificate of authenticity.

El impacto/The impact

Con los fondos recaudados, se trabajará en el desarrollo integral de las 3 familias evitando de esta manera su desintegración, devolviendo a los niños y niñas la oportunidad de volver a soñar con un futuro brillante.

Una familia es irreemplazable, y tu ayuda también. 

With the raised funds, we will work in the integral development of the three families, avoiding this way their separation, returning the children their chance to dream with a bright future again.

A family is irreplaceable, and so is your help.

Riesgos y desafíos/Risk and challenges

Una campaña toma tiempo y energía. Estamos comprometidos a hacer todo lo posible para ayudar a que esta campaña tenga éxito. Necesitamos que la recaudación de estos fondos para apoyar a las tres familias sea un éxito. No lo podemos hacer solos.

¡Únete a nosotros y difunde la campaña!

A campaign takes time and energy. We are committed to do everything we can to help this campaign to be successful. We need these fundraising to support these three families to be successful. We cannot do it alone.

Join us and spread the campaign!

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar/Other ways you can help

Algunas personas no pueden colaborar, pero eso no significa que no puedan ayudar.

Comparte esta campaña en tus redes sociales utilizando #FamiliaIrreemplazable para que muchas más personas se sumen a la causa. ¡Ayúdanos a llegar a más personas como tú!

¿No eres muy fanático de las redes sociales? ¡También puedes utilizar WhatsApp! Comparte la causa con tus contactos y así con la ayuda de todos lograremos brindarle un mejor futuro a estas familias que nos necesitan.

Some people cannot contribute, but it does not mean they cannot help.

Share this campaign in your social networks using #FamiliaIrreemplazable so that many more people join the cause. Help us reaching more people like you!

You are not a fan of social networks? You can also use WhatsApp! Share the cause with your contacts and this way, with everyone’s help we will be able to give a better future to these families who needs us.

Follow us on Facebook! 

Follow us on Twitter! 

Follow us on Instagram!
story_txt:
Resumen/Summary
La Convención de las Naciones Unidas sobre los Derechos del Niño (CDN), reconoce a la familia "como grupo fundamental de la sociedad y medio natural para el crecimiento y el bienestar de todos sus miembros, y en particular de los niños", y afirma que el niño, para el pleno y armonioso desarrollo de su personalidad, debe crecer en el seno de la familia, en un ambiente de felicidad, amor y comprensión. Adicionalmente establece que se deben realizar todos los esfuerzos necesarios para lograr que los niños permanezcan con su familia, se reintegren a ella, o en su defecto, se debe encontrar otra solución apropiada y permanente.
Sin embargo, por diferentes variables como la pobreza, migración, hacinamiento, violencia intrafamiliar, consumo de alcohol y drogas, o la situación de salud de padres y madres, el riesgo de desintegración familiar se incrementa, vulnerando de esta manera los derechos de los niños y niñas.
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, recognizes the family “as main group of the society and natural environment for the growth and welfare of its members, and specifically, children”, and says that in order to get the full and harmonious development of their personality, they have to grow within a family, in a cheerful, loving and understanding environment. It also establishes that all the needed efforts should be done to make children stay with their families, reintegrate to them, otherwise a proper and permanent solution should be found.
However, due to different reasons such as poverty, migration, overcrowding, family violence, alcohol and drugs consumption or fathers and mothers’ health, the risk of family disintegration increases, violating this way children’s rights.
Esta situación en Bolivia es alarmante y se refleja en las siguientes estadísticas:

6 de cada 10 niños y niñas viven en situación de pobreza.
3 de cada 10 niños y niñas sufren desnutrición crónica antes de los 5 años.
8 de cada 10 niños y niñas sufren violencia (física, psicológica y sexual)
Más de 165.000 familias están en riesgo de separarse.

This situation in Bolivia is alarming and is expressed in the following numbers:

6 out of 10 children live in poverty.
3 out of 10 children suffer chronic malnutrition before turning 5 years old.
8 out of 10 children suffer violence (physic, psychologic and sexual)
More than 165.000 families are at risk of separating.

Es por esta razón que Aldeas Infantes SOS trabaja en Bolivia más de 48 años en la prevención del abandono y la restitución del derecho a una familia de niños y niñas que perdieron el cuidado de sus padres.
That is why, SOS Children’s Villages works in Bolivia for more than 48 years, preventing the child abandonment and trying to restitute the right to a family for children who lost the care of their parents.
“Irremplazables” es una campaña de recaudación de fondos para atender a 3 familias en alto riesgo social, con el fin de asegurar su desarrollo integral y evitar de esta manera su desintegración
“Irreplaceable” is a fundraising campaign to help three families at high social risk, with the objective of assuring their integral development and avoiding this way their separation.
Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes/What we need and what you get
Necesitamos recaudar $15.000, los cuales cubrirán los costos directos de apoyo a estas 3 familias en las siguientes áreas:

Desarrollo integral de los niños y niñas: salud, educación, nutrición y desarrollo psicosocial.
Desarrollo de los padres, madres o cualquier otra persona que ocupe ese rol: autoestima, salud, pautas positivas de crianza, estimulación temprana, oficio laboral, y liderazgo.

Para todas las personas que nos ayuden, existirán recompensas ¡pensadas desde el corazón!, desde mensajes de agradecimiento hasta videos personalizados agradeciendo el compromiso con la causa, y también obras de arte exclusivas de un reconocido artista boliviano (Amigo de Aldeas Infantiles SOS) con su respectivo certificado de autenticidad.
We need to raise $15.000, which will cover the direct expenses of support to these three families in the following areas:

Integral development of children: health, education, nutrition and psychosocial development.
Development of fathers, mothers or any other person who is taking this role: self-esteem, positive childrearing guidelines, early stimulation, job and leadership.

For all the people who contribute, there will be rewards thought from the heart!, from thank-you messages to personalised videos thanking for the commitment to the cause and also exclusive works of art from a renowned Bolivian artist (a friend of SOS Children’s Villages) with its certificate of authenticity.

El impacto/The impact
Con los fondos recaudados, se trabajará en el desarrollo integral de las 3 familias evitando de esta manera su desintegración, devolviendo a los niños y niñas la oportunidad de volver a soñar con un futuro brillante.
Una familia es irreemplazable, y tu ayuda también. 
With the raised funds, we will work in the integral development of the three families, avoiding this way their separation, returning the children their chance to dream with a bright future again.
A family is irreplaceable, and so is your help.

Riesgos y desafíos/Risk and challenges
Una campaña toma tiempo y energía. Estamos comprometidos a hacer todo lo posible para ayudar a que esta campaña tenga éxito. Necesitamos que la recaudación de estos fondos para apoyar a las tres familias sea un éxito. No lo podemos hacer solos.
¡Únete a nosotros y difunde la campaña!
A campaign takes time and energy. We are committed to do everything we can to help this campaign to be successful. We need these fundraising to support these three families to be successful. We cannot do it alone.
Join us and spread the campaign!

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar/Other ways you can help
Algunas personas no pueden colaborar, pero eso no significa que no puedan ayudar.
Comparte esta campaña en tus redes sociales utilizando #FamiliaIrreemplazable para que muchas más personas se sumen a la causa. ¡Ayúdanos a llegar a más personas como tú!
¿No eres muy fanático de las redes sociales? ¡También puedes utilizar WhatsApp! Comparte la causa con tus contactos y así con la ayuda de todos lograremos brindarle un mejor futuro a estas familias que nos necesitan.

story:
Help Grow our Programs & Give Students a Healthy Lifestyle.

Kids Lacrosse The World and it's mission are simple:
To empower and educate students through the sport of lacrosse.

We use sport as a medium for community growth, leadership development and growing the game of lacrosse. Primarily a sport based in the United States, our program is on the cutting edge of developing youth-based programs serving students in rural communities through the game.

We are proud of our accomplishments so far, but understand that we have a ways to go.
2019 will be our most exciting and impactful year yet.

Here is why:

  • More development opportunities for our student athletes in Kenya and Malaysia.
  • With the addition of SMK Bintulu in Sarawak, Malaysia, we've grown our school footprint to (3) schools around the country. The program in Bintulu is thriving and we have a chance to develop our largest scale program in yet.
  • We plan to take our lacrosse teams to the next level: Training and preparing for local and international tournaments.

 

Impact thus far:

During our trip to Kenya this summer we supplied a LifeStraw Community water filter to our program in Butula. We noticed the effects that contaminated water has had, not only on our students, but the school entirely. With rolling power blackouts in the area, the water pump for filtering water at the school stops working. 

With this filter, we're able to provide a temporary solution for the schools staff. This allows them to filter with no electricity during those 1-3 day blackout periods; providing clean drinking water for students and teachers. This has been imperative for our students participating in lacrosse trainings and practice. 

 

During our trip to Malaysia this summer, we spent time at the Don Boscoe Rescue House - a home and learning center for refugees. Outside of our regular empowerment and lacrosse programming at the SMK Bintulu, SMK Ranau, and SMK Mat Salleh schools, our volunteer coaches and students educated groups on self-confidence and development.

 

Lacrosse Development & Youth Empowerment

Per our programming, we have been able to work with 500+ student athletes over the past 3 years. For 2019, our goals are simple: Grow, Impact and Become more Sustainable. 
 

Here's a few of our 2019 goals and initiatives: 

  1. Further lacrosse development in Kenya by working alongside other organizations in Kenya and Uganda; creating more exposure and opportunity for our students. This will involve sleep-away camps, tournaments and improved coaching.
  2. Powering and growing the SMK Bintulu Lacrosse Program in Malaysia. Started in 2018 by Rachel Frantz, the program has quickly grown in reputation and size. The emphasis on empowerment through lacrosse has been important in it's reach and we plan to support this program in it's entirety throughout 2019.
  3. Grow the Kids Lacrosse the World organization. Our goal is to host a long-term internship in Malaysia or Kenya this coming summer. With this improved program staffing, we will have a more profound impact in day to day activities.


Join us today and help provide the opportunities that many of us take for granted.

story:
Short Summary

The World Punjabi Congress (WPC) is a cultural nonprofit organization established in 1984 in Lahore with the purpose of promoting languages and culture for the attainment of peace and tolerance. The WPC has to date, organized more than 25 international conferences in Pakistan, India, UK, Austria, Canada, Sweden, Netherlands, Denmark, France and other countries.

World Punjabi Congress aims to achieve the following:

  • Nurturing cultural diversity through the promotion of national languages of Pakistan
  • Establishing peaceful relations between India and Pakistan through literary and cultural exchanges
  • Establishing linkages between Pakistani writers and writers of the world for the promotion of global peace and understanding
  • Providing a platform for dialogue among researchers and intellectuals for the dissemination of Sufi and cultural heritage of Pakistan

Our Aims

World Punjabi Congress has taken an initiative to organize a 3-day ‘International Conference on Peace’, in Lahore, Pakistan in the first quarter of 2019.

The Conference is the most effective way of persuading writers and intellectuals from Pakistan and all over the world towards achieving a goal of peace. It is meant to involve opinion-makers of the civil society and the common man of Pakistan in generating ideas regarding international peace with a predominant focus on Pakistan.

This mega-event will help consolidate efforts to show Pakistan's commitment towards promoting peace, harmony and a culture of tolerance. The Conference will also aim to disseminate the message of Sufism throughout the world, and to dispel the wrong notions associated with pseudo-religious propaganda that leads to extremism and intolerance. Pakistan is known all over for all the wrong reasons. With this Conference, we want to repudiate such wrongly perceived notions and bring out the soft, liberal and peaceful image of Pakistan.

Objectives of 'International Conference on Peace':

We expect about 80 delegates from around the world and 150 from within Pakistan. The objectives of this conference are:

  1. Instrument of intellectual discourse.
  2. Forum of developing diplomacy.
  3. Effort to re-shape the intellectual profile of Pakistan
  4. Making a point for the commitment of Pakistan to ‘Peace’.
  5. To introduce Pakistani literature, art and culture, for peace.
  6. Intellectual endeavor against terrorism, extremism and fundamentalism.
  7. Promotion of culture of tolerance, harmony and patience for mutual and interfaith dialogue.
  8. Introduction of the message of love, peace and humanism of mysticism.
  9. Protection of the basic human rights which protect against violation of peace and human freedom.
  10. Conflict resolution in the areas of conflict.
  11. For establishing peace and tranquility in the rising global strife by establishing international institutions like United Nations.

Importance:

          The international conference will be attended by 80 international delegates from 52 countries including the most illustrious peace activists, literary figures, scholars and educationists of the world. We will try to invite a couple of Nobel Laureates also. 150 selected Pakistani distinguished writers, artists, intellectuals, scholars and representatives of organizations working for peace in Pakistan will also attend the conference. Every delegate being an icon of intellect and expression, will be an opinion maker and image definer. The theme Literature, Art, Culture and Peace is likely to attract the world media, diplomatic circles and will help rediscover the real soul of Pakistan which is its unwavering commitment to peace.

Long-term Advantages:

          The conference with the presence of globally selected intellectuals and writers, pondering on a unique theme of Peace through literature, art, culture and documentaries will come up with a mutually accepted document “Pakistan Peace Declaration” in the Concluding Session. That declaration will show the world over that Pakistan is a most peace-loving country, rich in culture, art and literature.

Follow-up of 'International Conference on Sufism and Peace'

          The 3-day ‘International Conference on Sufism and Peace’ in March, 2010 in Islamabad was extremely successful in helping re-discover Pakistan as one of the liberal, progressive and peace-loving nations. Foreign and local delegates have expressed in their hundreds of articles written on Pakistan after attending the Islamabad Conference. The conference alone did wonders and made a perceptible difference in world image of Pakistan as a peace-loving country.

Please visit our website for more information:

http://worldpunjabicongress.com

We thank you for your support!

story:
Help Launch the Era of Values-Based Banking and Shopping

A message from the ecountabl team

If you aren't familiar with ecountabl, we’re a new kind of tech company with a simple but powerful purpose: To connect people with companies that share their values. Please explore our campaign to learn how our iPhone app links personal values to personal spending and helps you support the causes you care most about whenever you make a purchase.

Over the past several years we've invested our savings and sacrificed time with our families to build ecountabl from a great idea into an incredible company. This summer we reached a major milestone, debuting ecountabl in the App Store's beta testing program.

Now we need your help. Your donation will enable us to launch ecountabl to the American public. Contributors will receive early access to the ecountabl iPhone app (or access to the Android app when it's available), public recognition, and other special perks. Please use the social media tools at the top of the page to share our campaign with others.

We built this company to make a difference. With your support we can bring ecountabl to life and revolutionize the banking and shopping experience for millions of people, starting with you. Thanks so much, and we hope you'll join us on this remarkable journey.

- Andy Burr, Justin Bretting, Jason Hartke, Lotte Schlegel, Cody Taylor, Cindy Zhu, and Hiam Agha

 

Introducing ecountabl

Which brands share your values? Which ones are leading or falling behind on racial justice, gender equality, climate change, and human rights? Introducing ecountabl, the world's most powerful platform to help you manage your spending and find the best companies for YOU.



Simple and Powerful

Choose your values. Connect your spending. Find out which companies and brands in your life deserve to be there. View our 30-second ad spot and take a quick tour of the app.
 


An Experience Built Around You

Whether you’re passionate about social & environmental progress or just curious about your favorite brand or employer, you're in the right place. ecountabl meets you where you are, personalizing the experience based on your own values and transactions.


The Brands You Love

All the brands you know in one place. ecountabl puts trusted social and environmental information for more than 7,000 companies, brands, and employers at your fingertips.


Keeping Score

Our revolutionary ecountabl Score analyzes companies and your spending to find the best matches for you based upon your personal values and up to 48 data points per company. We do the hard work so you can make the easy choice.


See Something, Share Something

With just a few taps, start a conversation on social media with friends, family, and colleagues by sharing how your favorite brands perform on the issues you care about.


A Company You Can Believe In

We're using technology to empower people and business to work together to improve society. We're building an incredible company that you can be proud to support. See why we're so excited about the future.
 


 

Team

Great companies start with great people. Our founders, directors, and advisors have worked at the highest levels of global finance, digital retail, presidential administrations, mayor's offices, climate and environmental nonprofits, and technology startups.
 


 

Thanks from the CEO

When Jason Hartke and I met for breakfast a few blocks from the White House in 2017 to brainstorm the ideas that would become ecountabl, we didn't know that we had just started an incredible journey that would reshape how people live up to their values when they bank and shop. That journey has included our wonderful (and patient!) families; remarkable co-founders, team members and advisors; and amazing partners like Gender Fair, JUST Capital, and CSRHub. Now we hope it includes you, too.

Your support matters. First, it will help us to complete a critical product development period (familiar to many early-stage companies) where we have costs but no revenue yet. Second, it will enable us to launch ecountabl to the American public in early 2021, empowering millions of people to link their spending with their values and create personal impact. Every donation brings us closer to achieving that extraordinary goal. If you can't donate, you can still help by sharing our campaign using the social media tools at the top of the page. 

You can see more about us at www.ecountabl.com, including our founding story and my 2020 Letter to Prospective Investors describing the next-generation business tools we're building to help companies and their customers improve society together.

So much has happened since that morning more than three years ago and we're closer than ever to bringing ecountabl to life. On behalf of the whole team: Thanks so much for your generosity and support, and I hope to see you out there on this amazing journey.


Andy Burr, Co-Founder & CEO
Oct. 7, 2020
